Christian Island March 1, 1943

The Secretary Indian Affairs Branch Dept., Mines & Resources.

I would like to make an explanation re. Voucher no. 258 covering the non draft glass which I purchased on request of Mr Cowan Principal of the U. C. School.

The widows are so low in the school, that he asked if it would be possible to buy some glass to set on the inside of the windows to prevent the direct draft on the children when the windows are open, it was necessary to buy plate glass, then they had to be ground on one edge, to prevent the kiddies getting cut, I hope my action in this connection will meet with your approval. You will note that the kinder garden table did not cost very much, as we were able to make over an old table, and all that was necessary to buy was a few bits of lumber, and some oil cloth to cover it. Mr. Cowan did the work after 40¢.

Indian Agent.
STATEMENT

G E Hurk agent Feb 16 1943

The Secretary Indian Affairs Branch Dept., Mines & Resources.

In reply to yours of July 31, file 6-1-4. Sink in U.C. School.

Without asking the plumber to come to the island and measure up for the piping and sink, and thereby add to the cost of this job, he has given me a price of between $20.00 and $25.00. This will include the sink 18x28, cutting of the pipe and all necessary fixtures to hook it up.

The only addition to this will be the digging of a septic tank, and some material for walls in same, this will be done by the Indians. I would estimate that the job complete would not exceed $45.00.

Acting Indian Agent,
G. E. Hurl.
Ottawa,
September 16, 1943.

Mr. G.E. Hurl, Acting Indian Agent, Christian Island, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $45.00 for material and labour in installing the sink in the teachers' residence at the Christian Island U.C. School.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

" " " 4 P.M. 36

Jan. 21 - " " 9 A.M. 34
" 22 " " 9 A.M. 32

How can a teacher insist that pupils attend school on such days? We try to carry on in one room, but this is not conducive to good teaching results.

Reference is made to your voucher No. 106 and No. 99 dated August 15th, 1946, and August 13th, 1946, in favour of Gerald Monague and the Georgian Bay Tourist Company Limited, respectively.

On voucher No. 99 you state "Chargeable to Band Funds and Vote 76". The same confusion exists on your voucher No. 97, dated August 7th, 1946, which we note is a Credit voucher. When a Credit voucher is submitted it must be against an advance made for the purpose. Would you be good enough to give the number of the cheque which you received to be used in this connection. If you will destroy these vouchers and, in due course, return separate vouchers for each account we will arrange to pass them for payment.

The above remarks are not made in any spirit of criticism because we are aware of the fact that you cannot be expected to follow all the details of correct procedure until you have had an opportunity of familiarizing yourself with them. Extract from Acting Inspector J.E. Morris' report of his inspection of the Christian Island Agency dated June 23, 1943. Original on file 77-6 Ins.2.

United Church School.

Two room school with residence for two persons attached. The school is in good repair. The residence is on a foundation but there is no foundation, or cellar, under the school room section. There were complaints that the class rooms are very difficult to heat. Mr. Gauthier reports that he had the furnace pipes under the class rooms repaired and covered with asbestos last year, which made a big improvement in the heating. Consideration should be given to boarding up the lower part of the floor joist and fill it in with shavings and lime. This small repair could be done at little cost and, no doubt, would be very helpful.

There are no outside windows on the school, or residence. I would recommend that the Superintendent be authorized to purchase for the school 9 windows 5'6" x 3' and six outside windows for the residence 5'6" x 30".

The desks are in very bad condition. I would recommend that thirty of the new type desks be supplied - 10 small, 10 medium and 10 large.

It was drawn to my attention that in the senior class room, the windows with an eastern and southern exposure should have blinds. The Superintendent was instructed to purchase blinds and submit a voucher in the usual manner.

Sir,

In reply to your favor of the 21st inst requesting a report on the lack of educational facilities for the education of the children at the Dokis Reserve, I wish to say that owing to the isolated position of the Dokis Reserve, located as it is on the French River, about forty miles west of North Bay, it would be impossible for the children of this band (who number 17 of school age) to attend any white school in the vicinity of the Reserve, as I do not know of any white school being located within a very considerable distance of Dokis.

The only manner in which the children of this Band can be educated, would be by the establishing of a school at their Reserve, but owing to a lack of funds I do not see how this is to be accomplished at present. I may say however that the Dokis Band are the owners of one of the most valuable tracts of pine timber in this district, which if disposed of, or the proceeds therefrom placed to the credit of their Trust Fund, would enable them to establish and maintain a school for the education of their children, as well as to entitle each member of the band to a sum of interest money sufficiently large to purchase a great...
Sir,

many of the necessaries of life which they do not at present enjoy. The accomplishment of this most worthy object which would place the members of this Band in such a prosperous condition is prevented by the absolute refusal of Chief Pokio to consent to the sale of their timber; who being himself fairly well off, cannot be made to understand the many benefits which would accrue to the members of his Band through the sale of the timber, nor to appreciate the advantages which the establishment of a school on the Reserve, would give to the children of the Band.

I am therefore unable to see how any progress can be made in educational matters on this Reserve at present.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, 3rd Feb., 1903.

Memorandum:

Mr. Pedley,—

Superintendent Maclean, in his annual report, states that there are 32 children in the Dokis Band, French River, that they have no educational facilities whatever on the reserve, and that consequently the children are growing up without the advantages that education gives. I do not think the funds of this band will warrant any expenditure therefrom towards the construction and maintenance of a school on the reserve; but it is questionable whether it would not be advisable to ask Parliament to vote sufficient money for the purpose. I think that the refusal of these Indians to surrender their timber, to be sold for their benefit, is largely owing to their ignorance. If the timber were sold they would have ample funds to maintain a school of their own and pay for expenses incidental to the management of their reserve.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No203066/I of the 29th ultimo with reference to starting the school on the Dokis Reserve and report that I visited the Reserve with the teacher and have made arrangement to open the school tomorrow morning.

As previously reported the Chief is strongly opposed to this action and when I arrived there with the teacher and lumber to make desks and seats his manner caused considerable inconvenience in getting the building as previously arranged. The only excuse the Chief gives that He does not want the Department to use any of their money for school or other purpose.

When I was leaving the reserve the Chief brought up the question of children attending school who do not belong to the Dokis band. There are two families, Chertrand and Laravier, the women belong to the band but their husbands or children do not belong.

The Chief's brother Frank Dokis Sr has also two children of school age who belonged to his wife previous to his marriage. The Chief's brother has always encouraged the starting of a school upon the reserve against the Chief's wishes, and I am under the impression this move is to try and deprive the above two children of Frank Dokis attending school.

The Chief's action may affect the attendance but like the timber question will come around in time. On the whole the band is in favour of a school excepting three families.

May 23rd, 1927.

Mr. Agent Cockburn, who visited the Department today, was authorized to obtain a resolution of the Dokis Band to grant the sum of $4,000 from their capital funds for the purpose of erecting a school building. The Agent was also requested to obtain a quit claim deed for one acre of land as a site.

He will arrange to erect the building by day labour, under the charge of a competent white foreman, employing Indian labour as far as possible. He will purchase all material and forward accounts, and keep proper time sheets of the labour employed. The building to be erected is to accommodate 30 pupils, with cloakrooms for boys and girls. The building will be erected of logs, and the roof will be covered with rubberoid roofing shingles.

Mr. Cockburn will forward the resolution as soon as he obtains the same, when, after the necessary Order in Council is obtained, instructions will be given him to proceed with the work.

Sir:

In further reference to your letter of the first instant, regarding the application of Mrs. Joseph Jalbert for re-engagement as teacher of the Dokis Indian Day School for the next academic year, I have to say that a communication has been received from the Public School Inspector, who visited this school on the 4th instant. He states that he is not at all pleased with the condition of this school. He says the classes have made no progress during the past year and he recommends that a better qualified teacher be engaged for next term. The Inspector states that Mrs. Jalbert, while of good character and intentions, has been out of touch with teaching for so long, that it is very difficult for her to do satisfactory work.

The Department is of the opinion that there is an opportunity at this school to perform good service and therefore it is considered in the interests of the work that the services of Mrs. Jalbert be dispensed with at the end of the present school year and a qualified teacher obtained. You should, therefore, inform Mrs. Jalbert as soon as possible that the Department will not require her services after the school closes for the coming summer holidays. She should prepare the return, showing attendance, days taught, etc., for the current quarter, and forward same to your office, in order that payment of the salary due her can be made.

The Department has on hand a number of applications from qualified teachers, and the matter of a successor to Mrs. Jalbert will receive attention in due course. However, if you receive any applications from qualified teachers, you may forward same to Ottawa for consideration.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Mrs. Joseph Jalbert - Age 44.

Elementary English (Quebec) 9 years experience. Has not been teaching in the 14 yrs. previous to engagement in present school.

The teacher is a poor writer. The pupils are very backward. They were better last year. If this teacher is to be kept on in this or any other school, she should be required to qualify by attendance at Summer School.

If the best success is to be attained in a school of this type, the pupils should be given a thorough training in Oral English, in special periods in Form I, and in correlation with other subjects in the other grades. Dear Mr. Farris,

I was at my mission garden village trip recently, just a short while after you were there, and I would have liked to meet you.

Miss Addy, teacher that you met, has been 4 years at garden village and I am glad to hear that she is coming back. She was very encouraged when you told her that there was no complaint against her, which is absolutely true.

Two fallouts, at Dottie Bay, is doing fine and I wish she would come back. Dottie Bay is so lonesome that a young girl or boy can't stay there, or if they stay they go to French with the outsiders and become wild, according to the Indians' point of view, of course. There who rely troubles and complaints at Dottie Bay when a boy or girl was teaching there. So, I wish that third fallout would be re-engaged in the Indian service. I know of only one Indian kicking, but he doesn't even know how to sign his name, and in fact he kicked against every teacher.

To Mr. Geo. Cockburn, Indian agent.

Dear Sir,

They tell me that Miss Jallett was just re-appointed at Dottie Bay, surprising. I can't believe it for she is the best teacher we ever had in these since 1919. She has been teaching during 5 years when Dottie Bay had only a summer-school and one year in the school school.

Those who taught out of that period were young people, and because Dottie Bay is very hard to stay in and the people very hard to please, there was no one who did the work well. The three years before Miss Jallett's coming, there was a young man well qualified in the normal school, but he had no authority, no control, and the children learned nothing and he learned himself how to gamble, drink, and stay late at night. The same for the young girls who were teachers at Dottie Bay; as they were so immature and had to face first-class kickers, they sought for consolation and amusement with outside boys, increasing the mischief and troubles, and the children learned nothing.

Then, the conclusion is that no young people should be teaching at Dottie Bay, therefore she can't please the Indians who want a teacher quiet, giving good example, having control over the pupils, and making them improve.

Miss Jallett is the ideal for the Dottie Band.
she is quiet, aged, don't run after amusement to parties nor then she has a good control over the pupils, teaches them well, and so I am no more tired with complaints when she is there.

So, I ask you eagerly for the good of the Dottie Bay Band and for the good of the children in there as far as instruction and morals are concerned to endeavour to keep Miss Jallbut into this Ditto school.

I hope that the Department won't refuse us this great favor and that the new Interior Minister, Hon. Murphy will understand our situation.

Moreover, I belong to an order, the Jesuits order, which knows something about instruction and education, since it is our specialty, and who also, numerous as they are in Canada, can help considerably the Conservative Party.

So, dear Mr. Cashman, tell me the truth absolutely, is Miss Jallbut re-accepted or not? If she is not accepted, I am going to write to Honorable Murphy, to explain the situation about the Indian mission.

Yours Truly,

Rev. L. Porchon S.J.
Jesuit Indian missionary
St Ann's Rectory
Sudbury

Dear Sir,

According to the statement of an inspector you claim that Miss Jallott, the best teacher who was ever in Dots Bay, is not coming back. I declare that your inspector is wrong saying that she did not give satisfaction. She is aged, experienced, has control over the children, and made them learn something, although she is not qualified into the normal school. A second class does not give necessarily the gift of teaching.

The young Basil Horan, a 2nd class certificate, was at Dots Bay before Miss Jallott gave a circus and a show in the school during 3 years; the children could hear shootings coming from the school. Miss Cooper and Stella King, both of them having a 2nd class certificate, did not earn their wages. The best teacher I ever knew was Miss Addy, in supervising, Miss McDemott in Winnipeg, Miss Jallott in Dots Bay, yet they never went through normal school.

You may say: the inspector says so. He can't know about it fairly well. He goes in the Reserve once or twice a year, and I go 12 times a year. The inspector is well qualified, you may say. But I have been in the school and college and university for 5 years old till 35 years ago as a student, and I had my B.A. into an University. So, I know something about education.

So, I say that if a young girl is sent from normal school, even with a first class certificate,
is appointed to Dottie Bay's school, the trouble will start again, because a young person can't run that school. We had a quiet year, but that year, and I thought this will last, but I am afraid that the circus will start again in the school, if a young person is appointed there. And how the "kids" could learn when the teacher has no control over them, when he plays too much with them, or when he is afraid to touch any of the parents who run the school after all. So was the teacher Basil Moran.

I may say that the Indians at Dottie Bay, are very vicious and hard to please and interfere too much with the school business. So it needs a teacher, old and firm enough, to make them mind their business. Which a young teacher cannot do, generally.

So, considering the welfare of the Dottie school, I beg again the re-appointment of Mrs. Gilbert.

Yours truly,

Rev. L. Parchman
St. Ann's Rectory
Sudbury

Ottawa, June 30, 1931.

Sir:

Referring to previous correspondence regarding dispensing with the services of Mrs. Jos. Jalbert, teacher of the Dokis Indian Day School, I have now to inform you that, upon the strong recommendation of Rev. Father Porcheron as to the services Mrs. Jalbert has performed and also as regards her suitability for the position, the Department has decided to revoke the instructions given to dispense with her services, and will now approve of her re-engagement for the coming school year. Father Porcheron states that, although she has not professional qualifications, she is able to perform the duties of teacher to better advantage than a younger woman who might be professionally qualified.

I have, therefore, to request that you will inform Mrs. Jalbert that the Department will approve of her resuming duties when the school reopens after the present summer holidays, with salary at the same rate as previously allowed her. Please ascertain definitely from Mrs. Jalbert whether she will accept the position and inform the Department accordingly. I may add that we are informing Rev. Father Porcheron of the approval granted for the re-engagement of Mrs. Jalbert.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Miss Velma Gribbon of Pembroke is at present teaching in a Public School in the Dokis Indian Reserve West of Sturgeon Falls. This young lady has been practically isolated all winter and has been teaching under considerable difficulty. It appears that some of the Indians have gotten out of hand and are causing her considerable trouble.

The Indian Agent at Sturgeon Falls, Mr. Marleau was appealed to and he handed the matter over to the Royal Mounted Police. I contacted them and they said while the matter really should have been handled by Mr. Marleau, they would be glad to get Mr. Marleau and go in and see if they could adjust matters satisfactorily this week. In the meantime some of the adult Indians have advised Miss Gribbon that this is just what would likely happen and that they would not pay any attention to any gratuitous advice. We would write Mr. Charron, the Inspector, who has not appeared at the school yet but we do not know his address.

We will be glad if you could get in touch with him and have him go in and inspect the school immediately and get to the bottom of the dispute.

Yours truly,

McGaughey & Little,

Dear Sir;

In reply to your letter of May 27th with enclosure from Messrs. McGaughey & Little, concerning Miss Gribbons, Teacher at Dokis Indian School.

I have to report that Miss Gribbons did report some trouble to me a few weeks ago, and at that time told me that she had, before speaking to me already written to the R.C.M.P. in Ottawa. I told Miss Gribbons that we had R.C.M.P. at North Bay but that I would investigate the matter myself. Miss Gribbons did call at the North Bay office and one of the officers called me and told me that they would only go in with me.

I have had several letters and many verbal protests against Miss Gribbons recently. It was not a matter to be too impulsive about and I took time to hear all sides of the question. On May 26th I visited the school in the afternoon and found only 11 pupils, representing 3 families, present.

That night I held a meeting of all the men and women of the band. They were agreeable to send their children back to school but resented family matters being brought up by the teacher in class. Miss Gribbons did not follow my advice last October in selecting her boarding house, with the result that she has moved three times and left bad friends each time. She is also accused of having Indian boy friends, which has caused considerable jealousy among the village belles. In short, she is a complete failure as an Indian teacher.

Mr. Charron, Inspector, made his annual inspection on May 27th and reports that the pupils have only been retarded. I had occasion to judge Miss Gribbons' temper on Wednesday morning. After I had persuaded the Indians the previous night to send their children back to school, and with a class of 21 pupils that morning, the first thing Miss Gribbons did, I am certain she thought I had left the reserve, was to strap a big boy and send him home, for as she claimed, telling lies out of school. I think the matter is adjusted till the end of the term, as I advised Miss Gribbons that she must leave personal and private grievances out of school.

I am well aware of my responsibilities as guardian of my Indians, at the same time, according to Section 10, Paragraph 6 of the Indian Act, the R.C.M.P. is truant officer of an Indian Reserve and I presume that was Miss Gribbons' reason for writing to them. I did not take the R.C.M.P. to the reserve with me.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Superintendent, Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

J. A. Marleau, Indian Agent

WB.
With reference to the complaint of the above named, dated the 7th of May last which was forwarded to our Headquarters in Ottawa, Ont., this lady has been interviewed by the writer on two different occasions and this matter has been taken up with the Indian Agent at Sturgeon Falls, Ont. Different other reliable parties have also been interviewed who are well acquainted with conditions on the Dokis Indian reserve. A patrol was not made to the reserve to investigate this, as considerable expense would have to be incurred, and the complaint which appears to be a personal matter, does not warrant a patrol being made.

Miss GRIBBON has taught school on this reserve for the past season only. She is a very young lady and quiet small. She is of Irish descent and has a very quick temper,

On her arrival at the Dokis reserve last September, she became friendly with two or three of the young Indian men there, which caused a great deal of criticism. She boarded at an Indian home, and no other boarding houses are available on the reserve, and found it rather difficult to live with Indians and I found fault with the meals etc., and voiced her opinion to the Indian owner. Since this, she has moved from one Indian home to another and of course found conditions the same in each one. At the present time, she is forced to live in an Indian home there which is not any good, nor are any of the others, however, Miss GRIBBON feels that Indians should keep their homes in the same condition as any clean living white man would and has told them this, and the result is that she is not liked for this.

In the class room, Miss GRIBBON has tried to impress upon the pupils that they should live like whitesmen, not like savages etc., and in several cases has strongly criticized certain individuals on the reserve, in the manner in which they are living etc. The pupils in turn have carried this information to their parents, who in turn have accused Miss GRIBBON and told her that it is not her affair how the Indians are living and that she is in no position to criticize others. At the present time, none of the Indians on the reserve have any affection for Miss GRIBBON and are quite cold in talking to her about she is no good etc., and that she is only a man crazy woman.

From inquiries made, it has been learned that Miss GRIBBON has punished pupils in the school for something that their parents have done and the pupil was not to blame, such as the pupils coming to school not properly dressed and very dirty. She has also ordered other pupils out of the school and not to return again.

Valma GRIBBON - Dokis Indian Reserve.
Complaint of -

5. Miss GRIBBON, in the manner in which she has attempted to correct the faults of the pupils, and in an effort to correct the faults of the parents, through the pupils, and in the manner in which she punishes the pupils, she created a discord between the Indians and herself, and has lost all control of her pupils. Instead of trying to get cooperation from the older Indians, she has tried to dictate to them and now has them all working against her.

6. Miss GRIBBON called in at this office during the early part of May, and when questioned, stated that the older Indians are always insulting her, but as yet, have not assaulted her. When further questioned she stated that the Indians are always teasing her, telling her that she is no good etc., but have not used any vile language. She was also questioned on other matters concerning the use of liquor on the reserve and stated that once in awhile some of the Indians get some wine from somewhere, but that liquor conditions general, was good on the reserve. She was also questioned regarding the unpatriotic ideas that some of the Indians are alleged to have picked up from the American tourists, but could not supply any worth while information whatsoever.

7. In general, it appears that the Indians have teased Miss GRIBBON to such an extent that she can no longer bear it. The majority of the pupils in her school are far bigger in stature than she is and therefore, has not been able to exercise any discipline over them. These she orders to stay away from school and when the parents want to know the reason why, her temper gets the best of her, which has resulted in many hot arguments.

8. Mr MARLEAU, the Indian Agent states she is unsatisfactory altogether and will not be engaged for another season.

9. American tourists do not go to the Dokis reserve, although they may fish and hunt near by. A large number of the Indians on the reserve are employed as guides, but the tourists do not remain on the Dokis reserve, which is a large Island in Lake Nipissing.

10. For the reasons as stated above, it was not considered that a patrol should be made to the Dokis Indian reserve. The difficulties she is having can be cleared up by the Indian agent, however, if he requires any assistance, members of this Detachment will assist him. Fyle in this connection is being considered closed at this Detachment.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of September 12, 1946, concerning the re-opening of the Dokis Indian Day School, on the Dokis Reserve.

Yesterday I visited the Dokis Reserve, to ascertain the number of children who would attend school this year, and how many families will be moving into Sturgeon Falls, as has been customary in the past. Due to the re-opening of the Sturgeon Falls paper mill, in the near future, there is a shortage of houses in the town, consequently, the Dokis Indians will definitely stay on the Reservation. August 5, 1948.

Dear Mrs. Murphy:

I have for answer your letter of July 15 concerning the Rabbit Island Indian Day School.

I am fortunately now in a position to offer you a school which is not in the northern part of Ontario but which is situated in the central section. This is the Dokis Indian Day School, situated on Lake Nipissing, near Sturgeon Falls, Ontario. Yesterday I telephoned to Mr. Marleau, our Indian Agent at Sturgeon Falls, concerning the school and your possible appointment there.

This school has been closed during the winters for some years, due to shortage of teachers. Both the Missionary and the Agent have been very anxious to obtain the services of a full-time teacher this year. We have had a teacher there during the summer months but the children will require an experienced teacher to bring them up to standard again. I understand that most of the work will be with the primary grades, whereas at Rabbit Island you would have had all grades from one to eight, and a fairly large Entrance class.

The Dokis School has no teacherage but I understand from Mr. Marleau that a good boarding place is available at the rate of $40.00 per month. The school is reached by boat across Lake Nipissing and is rather isolated in the winter. However, the Indians are a fine type and I feel sure that you
will like it there.

If you want any other details concerning this school, accommodation, etc., I would ask you to write directly to Mr. J. A. Marleau, Superintendent, Indian Agency, Sturgeon Falls, Ont. I am sending him a copy of this letter so that he will be expecting to hear from you.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Mrs. L. Murphy,

Dear Madam:

In reply to your letter of August 9, I am pleased to read that you are interested in teaching at Dokis Reserve. The reserve is approximately 70 miles from North Bay, or 25 miles from Sturgeon Falls, on what is known as the Upper French River.

There are about 450 summer cottages and tourist resorts, on the various islands dotting the Upper French, in the vicinity of the reserve, and during the summer months transportation is very convenient. The Ontario Northern Railway operates a large boat, transporting tourists from North Bay to the French River. You could, if you wished, spend your weekend at North Bay or Sturgeon Falls. Boat service is also available from Sturgeon Falls.

The Indians of Dokis are all half-breeds, mostly of French and Scotch extraction. They receive a good income and live very well. They have good homes and speak either French or English at home.

During the winter months they have horses, and you can also travel by plane from North Bay.

The proposed boarding house for you is approximately 500 feet from the school. Mrs. Dokis was formerly a white person, and keeps a very clean house. They have no children. The previous and present teachers were both well pleased with the efficiency of Mrs. Dokis.

School attendance at present is 25, all between Grades 1 and 3.

I trust this is the information you desire, and will look forward to your arrival.

Yours very truly,

J. A. Marleau,
Superintendent

We are anxious to have our schools operate only on the regular academic year basis unless it can be proved that the Indian children can not attend during the winter months.

Ottawa, June 30, 1931.

Sir:

Referring to previous correspondence regarding dispensing with the services of Mrs. Jos. Jalbert, teacher of the Dokis Indian Day School, I have now to inform you that, upon the strong recommendation of Rev. Father Porcheron as to the services Mrs. Jalbert has performed and also as regards her suitability for the position, the Department has decided to revoke the instructions given to dispense with her services, and will now approve of her re-engagement for the coming school year. Father Porcheron states that, although she has not professional qualifications, she is able to perform the duties of teacher to better advantage than a younger woman who might be professionally qualified.

I have, therefore, to request that you will inform Mrs. Jalbert that the Department will approve of her resuming duties when the school reopens after the present summer holidays, with salary at the same rate as previously allowed her. Please ascertain definitely from Mrs. Jalbert whether she will accept the position and inform the Department accordingly. I may add that we are informing Rev. Father Porcheron of the approval granted for the re-engagement of Mrs. Jalbert.

Your obedient servant,

Geo. P. Cockburn, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sturgeon Falls,
Ont.

OTTAWA, 8th August, 1905.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent Cockburn, in his annual report for the year ended 30th June last, calls the attention of the Department to the fact that there is no school provided for the children of the Dokis Band. As far back as 1898 the Agent for this reserve pointed out the fact that these children were growing up in ignorance. There are about 20 children of this Band who could attend school. Although this Band owns a very valuable timber limit, which they are not disposed to sell, they have no funds of their own from which the salary of a teacher could be paid or a schoolhouse erected. It seems hard that the children should be made to suffer for the stubbornness of their parents, and if anything could be done to provide for their education, while they are making up their minds as to the disposal of their limit, I think it would be only fair that they should have the same advantages as all the other Indians of Ontario enjoy. The limit will no doubt eventually be sold, when they will be able to support the school.

Ottawa, July 8, 1908.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Ten years ago Mr. Maclean, who was then Superintendent at Parry Sound, called the attention of the Department to the fact that there was no school on the Dokis reserve and the education of their children was entirely neglected. He was asked to report the number of school age in the band and whether they might be sent to some white school in the neighborhood. He replied that the only way to educate these children would be to establish a school on the reserve.

Mr. Agent Cockburn has also brought this matter to the Department's notice, and now that these Indians are reaping in money it seems to me that a portion of it could not be better expended than in making provision for the education of their children. They have ample funds to build and equip an up-to-date school and pay for a first-class teacher, and I think it would be well that this matter should be attended to at once, so that another year may not pass without something being done for them in this direction.

Ottawa, March 28, 1912.

Mr. Pedley,

The question of the establishment of a day school on the Dokis Reserve has been before the Department at different times during the past fourteen years and we are no nearer a solution of the difficulty now than then. Mr. Agent Cockburn, who has tried time and again to induce the Indians to authorize the expenditure of a amount of money from their capital to put up a school building, reported on the 1st instant that he had recently visited the members of this band and found that the majority are opposed to the building of a school from their capital funds at the present time. It is pure stubbornness on the part of the older Indians which blocks the building of a school. They have a capital of over $730,000.00 to their credit. There are only 89 members all told in the band and there are between 20 and 25 children of school age and they are growing up in ignorance and something should be done to educate them.

The opinion of the Department of Justice is that the
the Department cannot use any portion of their capital for the building of a school-house on the reserve without their consent. They evidently know that they cannot have their money used for this purpose unless they are willing and it is for the Department to say whether they will allow the children to suffer or come to their relief.

The band could be charged with the teacher's salary and equipment and everything save the erection of the building. The Department will either have to give them a school building, obtain special legislation to take the money from their funds, or leave matters as they are now.

[Signature]

Memorandum:

The Department of Justice on the 25th day of May, 1899, gave an opinion with respect to the powers of the Governor in Council under Sections (now) 89 and 90 of the Indian Act, in which it was thought that a proposed expenditure under (now) Sec.90 for anything coming also within any of the classes mentioned in (now) Sec.89, would require the consent of the band.

I have discussed these sections and this opinion with the Department of Justice in connection with the Dokis Reserve School question as referred to in Mr. Benson's memorandum hereunder, and am advised that while these sections are not altogether clear, it is thought that Governor in Council could very properly expend the Capital belonging to a band for any of the purposes mentioned in Section 89 without the consent of the band, notwithstanding the provisions of Section 90 of the Act.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of March 1st and previous correspondence I beg to say that the Department has decided to erect a school building on the Dokis Reserve, payment to be made from the Capital Funds of the Band notwithstanding their objection to this. It is considered that in the interest of the children this step should be taken.

I have to ask you, therefore, to be good enough to give the Department information as to the number of children that should be provided for; the kind of building that should be put up; whether accommodation should be furnished for a teacher or not and, if so, of what nature and to what extent; how the work should be done, whether by day labour or contract; means of communication between the reserve and the nearest point from which materials, etc., can be transported and such other information as you may consider necessary. I may say that it does not appear that the Department has at the present time any plan suitable for this building. For Whitefish Lake on the north shore a plan has been prepared providing living quarters at the rear with two rooms upstairs and two down. This plan, however, is for a building to accommodate 36 children, which would be altogether too large for the Dokis Reserve. I should be pleased to have this information above.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Mr. Agent Cockburn, who visited the Department today, was authorized to obtain a resolution of the Dokis Band to grant the sum of $4,000 from their capital funds for the purpose of erecting a school building. The Agent was also requested to obtain a quit claim deed for one acre of land as a site.

He will arrange to erect the building by day labour, under the charge of a competent white foreman, employing Indian labour as far as possible. He will purchase all material and forward accounts, and keep proper time sheets of the labour employed. The building to be erected is to accommodate 30 pupils, with cloakrooms for boys and girls. The building will be erected of logs, and the roof will be covered with rubberoid roofing shingles.

Mr. Cockburn will forward the resolution as soon as he obtains the same, when, after the necessary Order in Council is obtained, instructions will be given him to proceed with the work.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing a resolution of the Dokis Band authorizing that the sum of $4,000 be taken from the funds at their credit in Capital Account for the purpose of erecting a school building and requesting that a plan and specifications be sent you.

In reply I have to say that we are sending you, under separate cover, a blue print plan which was made for another school, which you may use as a guide. You may find it necessary to make some minor changes in order to work in the log construction.

It was understood at the time of your recent visit to the Department that you could arrange to have the building erected of logs, under the charge of a competent foreman, employing Indian labour as far as possible, also that you would purchase all materials and keep proper time sheets of the labour employed. Ottawa, June 23, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, enclosing a quit claim deed, in duplicate, for one acre of land for a site for the proposed new Indian day school on the Dokis Reserve, which is satisfactory.

Relative to your request that the building to be erected should be of frame construction rather than of log, I have to say that, in view of your recommendation, the Department will approve of a frame building being erected. You should have the man whom you engage as foreman on the work assist you in preparing an estimate of the lumber and other building material required, and you should then arrange, after obtaining competitive prices, for the purchase of same. You should see that all material is obtained at the most advantageous price. As instructed in our letter of the 9th instant, the work of erecting the building is to be under the charge of a competent foreman and Indian labour should be employed as far as possible. You may arrange to have the work started as soon as possible, and all costs should be kept down to the lowest possible point. The blue print plan sent you should be used as a guide in the construction of the building.

You should select the best possible site on the acre of land obtained for the erection of the building.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, May 23rd, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant, informing the Department that Rev. L. Percheron has a 60 pound church bell which he offers to sell for the sum of $15 for the use of the new school building on the Dokis Reserve.

In reply I beg to say it is considered that a bell of this size would be small for school purposes. Where we have supplied bells for Indian schools, the weight, including mountings, has been approximately 125 pounds. Do you consider that the bell offered by Father Percheron would be large enough to meet the requirements. Please also state what arrangements you could make to place this bell at the school. Is there a belfry on the school building, and, if not, where would the bell be placed? When we have the information asked for, consideration will then be given to the purchase of the bell referred to by you.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No 42-1-5 of the 23rd instant, with reference to the Church-bell, that the Reverend L. Percheron, Indian Missionary has offered to sell for $15.00 for use of the new school building on the Dokis Reserve.

I now beg to report that the weight of the bell submitted was not correct as given as 90lbs, the bell weighs 178lbs, and is in good condition, and would be suitable for the school. There is a suitable belfrey on the school building, the cost of freight and having the bell placed in position would not exceed $7.00. I beg to recommend the purchase.

Ottawa, May 30th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th instant, with reference to the purchase of a church bell from Rev. L. Percheron for the use of the new school building on the Dokis Reserve. It is noted that the bell weighs 175 pounds, is in good condition and would be quite suitable for use at the school, also that there is a belfry on the school building in which the bell could be placed.

The Department will approve of the purchase of this bell for the sum of $15, and will also pay the cost of the freight and having the bell placed in position in the belfry. If any bell rope or other supplies are required in installing the bell, you may arrange for the purchase of same. You should see that the bell is properly installed.

You may forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, in favour of Father Percheron covering the cost of the bell, and also an account, in duplicate, covering the freight and placing of the bell in position in the belfry at the school.

Your obedient servant,

August 14th, 1919

To Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

I have been advised by our missionary at Albany that 15 families have left there to make headquarters at English River and that others are contemplating the same move. They have been attracted by higher prices for furs and cheaper goods. We have been visited by several weeks ago and confirmed in the above report. This means that there will be a goodly number of children—some 30 at least—at English River whose education should be provided for. I had thought several years ago that a teacher and school should be commenced at this place, but the number of children was small then and the outbreak of the war caused me to give up the idea. Now conditions are ripe and call for action as soon as possible.

I had some correspondence with our missionary at Albany who visits English River every summer as one of his charges. He also concurs with my plan and urges an immediate start with the school work. He has forwarded the enclosed proposition for that purpose. We cannot do anything this year, but I would like to have the material ready for next summer. I propose sending a man there by November across down the Saguenay River next May. He will teach the school for the summer.

Dear Sir,

I have not received the promised advice contained in your letter of August 25th, 1919 regarding the establishment of a day-school at English River.

Dear Sir,

I have heard of the 6th visit in reference to the establishment of a summer school at English River. I am very much disappointed that the Department feels unable to undertake the costs of school material and a salary for the leader at the usual rate of $30 per month. This was undertaken earlier at the usual rate of $30 per month, and the splendid results have fully justified the step. I would not ask for anything that was not "absolutely required." I have had this idea for some years and each visitation of a school at English River for some years and each session has confirmed me strongly the need of such.

If the Church offers the use of a building, I shall be glad to offer the use of a building, especially as the Department should meet us half way, especially as the Department owes the duty of the Indians to provide education. The Department owes the duty of the Indians to provide education. We pay the missionary a salary for the whole year while the Department provides only a stipend for the 3 or 4 months of the summer session. I am sending the missionary in any case as I have already engaged him and made arrangements for his transportation which is considerable and paid by us. I hope the Department will consider this matter and at least furnish the school material, if not the salary.

Right Reverend Sir,

In further reference to Your Lordship's request for the establishment of a summer school at English River I beg to inform you that, upon further consideration, the Department has consented to provide a grant at the rate of $50.00 per month towards the salary of the teacher. This will be paid upon the receipt of the usual quarterly returns, showing the attendance, days taught, etc.

With reference to the furnishing of school material I beg to say that the Department will also be prepared to send a reasonable quantity of supplies, if instructions are given as to how it could be sent in to English River. Messrs. Revillon Bros. informed the Department that their scows would be leaving Pagwa on the 25th of this month and it is now too late to have these supplies sent in by them. The Department cannot furnish desks for this school until it is assured of the success which is met with by the teacher during the coming summer.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

A request has been received from His Lordship the Bishop of Moosejaw for the opening of a school for the summer months at Marten's Falls. He compares the conditions at this point with those at English River, where a school was open last summer from May 1st to August 31st. The pay list shows that there are 77 children at Marten's Falls and the Bishop states that there are at least 25 of these of school age. He states that he has been fortunate enough to secure the services of a teacher, Mr. A. E. O. Anderson, a student from St. John's College, Winnipeg, to carry on the work. Mr. Arey informs me that there is a church building at this point and, no doubt, the school would be conducted in that building.

His Lordship also requests that the school at English River be re-opened next summer. The cost of this school for the past summer was as follows:

| Item                        | Cost   |
|-----------------------------|--------|
| Teacher's salary, 4 months  | $200.00|
| Rent of building, 4 months  | $40.00 |
| Stationery and school supplies | $32.79 |
| **Total**                   | **$272.79** |

The school at English River, from reports received, seems to have been successful, having had an enrolment of 57 pupils, with an average attendance of 29.

I would beg to recommend that the school at English River be re-opened and that a trial be given during next summer to the work of conducting a school at Marten's Falls. The expense of carrying on the work at these points during the summer would be about $250.00 at each point. This is the only opportunity the children have of receiving any education.

Ottawa, April 21st, 1925.

Right Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 18th instant, informing the Department that you have arranged with Mr. R. Dawson, of St. John's College, Winnipeg, to take charge of the Indian summer day school at English River, and that he will begin duties on or about May 1st, next. In reply I beg to say that the Department approves of his appointment, and salary will be allowed him at the same rate as was previously paid.

With reference to the school material required, I beg to say that the requisition for the previous year has been duplicated, and the supplies have been forwarded by the Stationery Office, here, addressed to the Missionary in Charge, English River Post, and were sent c/o Revillon Freres, 134 McGill St., Montreal, securely packed. These supplies were shipped from the Stationery Office on the 7th of February, last.

Supplies were also forwarded at the same time for the schools at Moose Fort and Albany Mission.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

February 14th, 1916.

Dear Bishop Anderson -

I have your letter of the 11th instant, with enclosure from Rev. Mr. Richards of Fort Hope. I shall make enquiries regarding the payment of the grants.

I am pleased to learn from Mr. Richard's letter that the Indians in the neighbourhood of Fort Hope are not suffering from any want. I return, as requested, his letter to your Lordship.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Right Rev. J. G. Andersen,
Bishop of Moosehead,
Cochrane, Ont.
Diocese of Moosonee

JOHN G. ANDERSON
BISHOP
Bishop's House
COCHRANE, ONT.

Feb. 18, 1916

Duncan C. Scott Esq.,
Deputy General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

My dear Mr. Scott,

I have received a cheque from the Dept. of $50 in payment of salary of Mr. E. Richards, St. Hope School, for the Sept. and Dec. quarters of 1915. I have not received payment for the June quarter. Evidently the Department has not received the returns through the mail. Mr. Richards testified that he enclosed letters from Mr. Richards testifies that he forwarded the returns in due course. They may yet reach the Department, as I have had letters not only long delayed but sometimes lost altogether. I am afraid that the same has happened regarding the Mississinewa School. I had a letter the first of October, only one for some fourteen months. From Mr. Richards' letter will interest you as showing the condition of the Indians on the Athabasca River. Unless you have any wish to obtain the letter kindly return to me.

With best wishes,

Sincerely,

[Signature]
John G. Moosonee

Sept. 15th 1926

Dear Sir,

I have been away from home for 3 months and am now arriving here in a letter postmarked July 28th. Teacher's salary (Fort Hope) amounting to $112.50.

May this amount paid. May be that the teacher was absent on missionary work for part of the month. If so, that is all right, but I hope the balance will not be lost because the teacher was most convenient for his work, but rather holidays when most convenient for his work, that is, he will teach in July and August, which are the usual holidays as arranged by your Department.

Yours sincerely,

John G. Moosonee
Ottawa, September 10, 1926.

Right Reverend Sir:

In reply to Your Lordship's letter of the 7th instant, I beg to say that, as the June quarter return of the Fort Hope School showed that the school had been open for only 2½ months, we allowed salary for that period of time only. I note that the school has been open during July and August, and, when this teacher forwards his September quarter return, it will no doubt show the exact number of days it was in operation. We will then make payment of the balance which you mention is due.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Reverend Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, enclosing the June quarter return of the Fort Hope Indian Day School.

I note your statement that you have not received any bonus cheque for the quarter ended March 31st, 1927. In this connection I would point out that payment of bonus to teachers of Indian day schools was discontinued from March 31st, 1926. Previous to that time, salary was paid at the Fort Hope Indian Day School at the rate of $300 a year, plus bonus of $150 a year, or a total of $450. Since April first, 1926, the salary allowed at this school has been at the rate of $450. You will note, therefore, that the salary at the present time is as large as when the bonus was being paid. When the returns have been received, cheques in payment of salary at the above rate have been forwarded to Right Rev. J. G. Anderson, Cochrane, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. D. Macdonald,
Fort Hope Mission,
via Tashota, Ont.

JOHN G. ANDERSON
BISHOP

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

In checking over the school accounts for the year 1929 I notice that the grants for the Fort Hope school for the June and Dec. quarters as well as for the month of September have not been paid. The last grant I received was for the March quarter.

I notice also that no grants for 1928 have been paid for the Albany school. The Rev. P. A. Northam fell sick last July so that the returns for the March quarter at least should have been sent in. The school, I know, has been regularly kept by the Rev. Andrew Wesley, native assistant minister, who has so informed me by his letter written in English. Though able to teach school quite well, he may not be able to make out the returns. This too soon, of course, to expect the returns from Fort Hope for both June and Dec. quarters.

I shall be glad to have your decision or information on the above at your convenience.

Yours sincerely,

John G. Moosonee
Ottawa, February 11th, 1930.

Right Reverend Sir,-

In reply to your letter of the 7th instant, I beg to say that the salary of Rev. D. Macdonald, teacher of the Fort Hope Indian Day School, for the quarters ended June 30th, September 30th and December 31st, 1929, have been paid. Through oversight, cheques for these three quarters were sent direct to him instead of to you. A note has been made and future cheques in payment of the salary at this school will be forwarded to you.

The last return received from the Albany River Indian Day School was for the quarter ended December 31st, 1928, and, consequently, no salary has been paid since that time.

The return of the Fort George Day School for the quarter ended June 30th, last, has been received and cheque for $150.00 forwarded to the Royal Trust Company, Montreal. The September and December quarter returns have not yet reached the Department.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier.
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rt. Rev. John G. Anderson, D.D.,
Bishop of Moosonee,
Bishophorpe,
Cochrane, Ont.

FORM 14
Ottawa, July 31st, 1931.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 25th instant, requesting permission to continue in operation the Indian day school at Fort Hope during the current quarter ending September 30th and to take the annual holidays during the months of October and November following.

In view of your report that there would be a more regular attendance of the Indian children if holidays were taken during the months mentioned, the Department will approve of this arrangement. You should, therefore, keep the school in operation until the end of September and re-open it again after the holiday period, on December 1st, next. Please forward, at the end of the quarter, the usual return showing attendance, days taught, etc.

Your obedient servant,

A. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. A. Macdonald, Esq.,
Teacher,
Indian Day School,
Fort Hope,
via Tashota, Ont.

Ottawa, January 24th, 1935.

Sir,-

The Department has just received the December quarter return of the Fort Hope Indian Day School and the amount due the teacher for that period is $135. As you are aware, we have forwarded cheques in payment of the teacher's salary at this school to you for some time past and you have credited same to the Diocese of Moosonee.

Owing to present regulations, salary cheques have to be issued in favour of the person performing the service and, as Rev. D. Macdonald is the teacher of the Fort Hope School, we are issuing the cheque in his favour and forwarding it to you. This letter will give you the necessary information in order that you may credit the amount to the proper account.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

The Manager,
Royal Trust Company,
St. James Street,
Montreal, Que.
April 1st, 1935.

Note for File:

Sir,

I have the honor to herewith enclose minutes of a meeting held by school election at French Bay Saugeen Reserve.

The meeting was called to fill the vacancy made in the Eldée Board by the death of Mr. Bathwassagonoby. I do not think they made a good choice, but as the school & school affairs is principally managed by the Council & Dept., it does not so much matter.

I would therefore ask the Dept. to sanction the appointment of Samuel Wahbeyes as one of the Trustees for French Bay School Section.

In reference to the vote taken whether or not they retain the present teacher Miss Helen Cameron, it is conclusive that the majority is in favor of change.

The desire for change being a characteristic of the Indians does not indicate that the pupils would be benefited thereby. She fulfils the purpose has to the teacher, as that their school is not progressing as well as the other schools on the reserve, this is owing to a great extent to the irregularity of attendance of pupils.

In my opinion this teacher is well qualified especially on account of her long experience, being so well acquainted with the Indians which is essential to progress in an Indian school she perhaps has not the force of character that some teachers have to command control, but if the pupils attended regular I believe she could do as good a work perhaps better than a teacher without experience in Indian Schools which if we made a change he would be likely to get.

Shame the honor to be sir,
Your obedient servant,
John Scofford

Sir,

I have the honor to call your attention to the unfortunate state of affairs now existing in connection with the Indian day school on the Saugeen Reservation. The facts as represented to us are these: Miss Cameron, the present teacher of the school has been in charge for about nine years, and during that period from evidence supplied us it would seem her services have been satisfactory. It appears, however, that an effort is now being made in the face of the protest of the majority of the Indians on the Reservation to have her removed and have another teacher of another denomination put in her place. Miss Cameron is a member of the Methodist Church, and the majority of the Indians belong to the same body. A requisition signed by the Indians both at Saugeen and French Bay has been sent to us expressing the wish that Miss Ellen Cameron be allowed to continue to teach at least until the close of the year. Of course the school receives no grant from the Missionary Society, but the majority of the Indians being Methodists feel that under the circumstances their present teacher ought to be allowed to remain, and that something approaching denominational prejudice or preference on the part of the Agent enters into the attempt now made to discontinue the services of the present teacher. I write

French Bay, March 24, 1900,
To the Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Gentlemen:

Your Indian Agent,
Mr. John Scuffield, received a report from me in the work of your recently appointed caretaker for this school, and in all probability such report has reached you prior to this.

Mr. Scuffield informed me, when I took charge of this school, that your department demanded of me a correct report, giving day and date of the work of the caretaker, as such caretaker was simply appointed on trial. I said to your agent that this was hardly fair, as he knew
and acknowledged to me prior to my coming here that no Indian boy could be secured to do the work properly, and it was in his authority that I applied for the position in February before I came here. Therefore, I must report the facts; and according to his opinion the facts would not be favorable to the Indian caretaker, and hence would naturally antagonize the Indians against me. I have reported in good faith and tried my best to get the little Indian boy to do his best. When he opened the door in the morning and put on the fire and rang the bell within a few minutes of 9 o'clock, the 8 o'clock...
hill I mean, and when the pupils and myself were nearly perished with cold, I told the boy I would be compelled to report him to the Department; his father sent me a note, telling me as follows—“Well, dear Sir, you may first report Joseph to Department. I never said anything to a teacher before, that was here. Mr. Jesse Root.” This is the note in full, and shows, when read between the lines, the mailed Indian threat of trouble ahead. Now I am not wanting the job of caretaking for myself, if it can be at all done by some other means, I do not want the ill will of the Indians for the sake of a twenty dollar job. If the Department is satisfied I
I am willing to try and do the best I can under the circumstances. I had the Inspector (Mrs. Alexander) a few days ago and he was highly pleased with the improvement in the school. He said to me, "Mr. Wallace you have perfect control and you are going to do splendidly here." The Department is anxious to get good faithful teachers for the Indians and will be pleased at your success. You may, perhaps, have his report by this time. Now it is too bad to have my influence blighted just at the outset. I would suggest that the Department, by some means, endeavour to make it understood by the "Indian Committee" that I was but faithfully
the mandate of the Department, when I reported, and as a servant of the department was compelled to obey them, otherwise the responsibility would rest upon my shoulders in the care of school furniture &c., for this is what your Agent informed me at the outset.

I cannot be responsible for school appointments (e.g., over which I have no control from 4 P.M. until 9 A.M. not including Saturdays, Sundays and vacations), nor can I assume such a responsibility, where I am deprived of the authority to carry out the same.

Your humble servant,

J.G. Wallace, Teacher, French Bay School
Gentlemen,

After giving the subject serious consideration, I would beg to say, that so long as the Indians see any opportunity of securing the $20 salary attached to the position of caretaker, they will be making trouble with the teacher, and would do anything to have him removed, in the hope that a change of teachers would throw the position open and thus give them a chance to secure it.

If the position of caretaker could be attached permanently to the position of teacher for $825 per annum all this trouble would be obviated for all time. The Indian agitation would cease and it would greatly strengthen...
the hands of the teacher, as they would have no object in creating trouble. One thing is certain, the efficiency and usefulness of the school and teacher is going to be greatly interfered with if the care and attention remains in the hands of an Indian. They have no clocks and depend on the school bell entirely, so that when it is not properly and regularly rung, the government's school is almost lost. I am a life long supporter of the Reform party and am proud of our success and therefore do not make these suggestions for impertinence but because I know my party is always anxious to do what they consider best. Your humble servant,

J. G. Wallace
Report of the work of the Caretaker of French Bay School, Longuean Indian Resv.

February 6th
Pupils allowed to re-enter school-room after teacher had left, thus injuring the school property by running and playing through the room and jumping from desk to desk.

7th
Teacher warned the caretaker against allowing the other children to come in to school-room after dismissal at 4 o'clock, to no purpose as the same thing occurred the same evening. Teacher also instructed caretaker to sweep the room thoroughly at night and dust with a damp cloth in the morning, telling him also to report the names of any children who refused to keep out of school-room after 4 o'clock.

8th
Teacher compelled to leave his own residence and go to the school-room to protect the school furniture from being smashed by the running of caretaker himself with a number of other children whom he encouraged to re-enter. Teacher assumed control, sent the children to the road again, and once more explained to caretaker his duties in care of school-house and school property.

13th
Teacher compelled to go out of his own house into full view on the yard in order to stop the caretaker from running in and over the kids of the school-desks and leaping from the top of one to the other. Stone chucked with ashes. Caretaker requested to remove same to no purpose.

Floor unclean, no broom to sweep with, no dusting done since caretaker assumed control.

15th
Fire lit at 25 minutes to 8 o'clock and 8 o'clock bell rung at same time.

16th

Hon. Mr. Hilton, Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs,

Hon. and dear Sir,

I humbly beg to be allowed to bring to your notice the very small salaries which we, as teachers on the Sanger Indian Reserve, are receiving and to pray you to raise our remuneration on a par with the teachers in the surrounding White Schools.

During the past three or four years teachers' sala have advanced substantially in the province. Inspector of public schools (Mr. Clendenning) informs me that salaries have advanced very substantially in all the schools under his care except the Indian schools. Our families are isolated, we have many discouragements to contend against unknown to those in White settlements. My wife has never been able to leave French Bay or to associate with her own race since last summer, cost of living has advanced rapidly since we came to this Reserve four years ago and notwithstanding all this our salary remains fixed at twenty-five dollars a quarter. I have to support a family of five members on the sum a thing I could not accomplish were it not that the Missionary Society helps me a little and the same help had to be extended to Mr. Burr of Scotch Settlement since last midsummer.

I am well aware these conditions might exist without your knowledge if your attention were not especially directed to them. Having your high sense of honor and justice as a public man and a citizen of the Crown I make bold to lay our case before you, fully believing the justice of our prayer will lead you to extend unto us what assistance you may see our case deserves.

Yours, respectfully,

Dear Sir,

On passing the Agent's office this evening at Chippewa Hill, your Agent, Mr. Scalford called me into his office. On going in I found Constable Henry Ritchie there and with him Elijah Ahnawquet whom he had arrested under Mr. Scalford's warrant for not obeying a summons issued by the Agent some time ago in sending a boy to school whom he is the guardian.

The Agent led me to understand that the said Elijah Ahnawquet acknowledged his fault and had requested the Agent to report a line of defense to the Department, coupled with a request to have the fine remitted and the Department to relieve the said Elijah Ahnawquet of the duty of sending the boy to school any longer.

As your Agent knows little about the history of Elijah Ahnawquet's case except the version given by Elijah himself, it seems to me a short-sightedness of Elijah's and in school matters will enable the Department to decide this matter not in the best interests of Elijah but in the best interests of French Bay school and the schools in general in this Reserve.

1. This is his second offense in disobeying a summons in the education of his children.
2. During my 11 years experience in French Bay school, he has given continuous trouble in educating his children.
3. He has raised a family of 3 boys and 6 girls all almost destitute of education.
4. Every possible means was used to get him to obey the Law prior to his being summoned.
5. He willfully and persistently endeavored to over-ride the Law and ignore it evidently his aim being to break the Law down and discount entirely.

6. He failed to over-ride the law, and now when he discovers his failure, he attempts to snatch a victory by crying and pleading for sympathy.

7. He has no necessity for contributing towards the support of any of his legitimate children as they are all grown up and should be able to look after themselves. He has his wife and the boy Jerry an illegitimate son of Elijah Ahumugwato own daughter and on whose account he was summoned. His family consists of 3 including himself.

8. Mrs. Angus, who knew the mother of the boy Jerry, informed David Root, my Tenant Officer, that she requested Elijah Ahumugwato and Mrs. Ahumugwato (her father and mother) to give the boy up to her and her husband and they would keep him and educate him. Elijah Ahumugwato and Mrs. Ahumugwato refused her request.

9. It is said the boy Jerry was sent to school one week but failed to come. I know that he was out of school Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. On Thursday evening my Tenant Officer reported him to the Agent, and the next morning, Friday he was at school bright and early. He then came the following Monday, Tuesday, and Thursday. As Elijah had not yet received his summons, imagining the affair had blown over the boy Jerry was out of school again. A few days after this Elijah received his summons which he entirely ignored. His daughter (the boy's mother) and her husband were summoned as witnesses. They ignored their summonses too.

10. Five of Elijah Ahumugwato's children including Jerry the boy in question, attended my school in their time. 3 were taken out of school under age, one died and now Jerry is sought after to follow the same course.

11. Jerry is a member of my 2nd Part class, and pure at that.
12. I attempted to get Mrs. Elijah Ahnwegecut to send this boy Jerry to school when he was over 6 years of age. My Tenant Officer came to me and reported that Mrs. Ahnwegecut declared to him that Jerry was only 3 years old. The Tenant Officer told me then that he himself knew Jerry was about 7 years old.

13. Taking the children out of school all too soon is a great evil in these schools and to my mind should be discouraged.

14. It requires some moral courage on the part of a teacher to brave the ill-will of these ignorant parents who refuse to properly educate their children. Fortunately these ignorant ones are in the minority.

These facts are submitted for the consideration of the Department. The Agent's report may not reach you until later.

It will be in the best interests of my work here for the Department to consider this report as confidential unless it becomes a necessity to return a copy to the Reserve. In such case I am prepared to substantiate every statement it contains.

I have the honor to be your humble servant,

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform the Indian Department that Jerry Ahwamow's friends have broken their solemn promises to send Jerry to school regularly according to the Regulations, three times in succession already.

Sending a boy regularly according to the Regulations means sending him every day for the full term during which the school is open. See Regulations section 1.

"The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department see Instructions to Teachers, Page 1. Quarterly Report.

The hours approved of by the Department are from 9 o'clock in the morning of every legal school day until 4 o'clock in the evening. Each school day to consist of two sessions viz. 9 A.M. to 12 A.M. and from one P.M. to 4 P.M. Every teacher being vested with the authority to refuse to admit a pupil to take a seat in the school-room who is not in his or her seat at the opening of the session viz. 9 o'clock A.M. and 1 o'clock P.M.

Coming into the school-room and interrupting the classes at any hour of the forenoon was,
and always has been Jerry's pet methods of annoying the teacher. An appeal to his friends only caused the offensive habit to be aggravated. When I had exhausted all my powers of moral suasion in an effort to correct Jerry's bad habits as a last resource I used the switch. On this being done Jerry's grandmother, Elijah Ahumocoot's wife, actually came into my school and abused me first in the Indian language in the presence of the entire school while the school was in session. Not content with this method of abuse she finally assaulted me and I was compelled to eject her from the room. She refused to go until I was forced to remove her by force. The department will clearly understand that I am prepared to prove every statement I shall make in my letters. I have been working throughout for this boy's good and the good of the community. In his present environment I can do nothing to prepare him to become a useful citizen. At the very best you cannot hold him in this school long enough even to do him much good. His friend's promises are not worth the paper they are written upon, and no man knows this better than your agent for he has tried the promised time and again at Scotch settlement under Mr. Burr. I never allowed it here.
I am convinced the officers of the Brantford Institute will act very well, will do all possible to give him an education and to make of him a useful citizen. My only hope for Jerry is to have him removed from his present environment and away from these new friends and placed in some Institute where he will be under kind but firm restraint. The very best Indian parents on this Reserve exercise no control over their children, give them no moral training whatever. Young girls and boys of tender years will leave home and be away for days and the parents know nothing of their whereabouts or what they are doing. The only person on the Reserve who exercises any control over them for good is the teacher. The Agent seldom or never comes in contact with them and they fight shy entirely of the missionary. The teacher, in his school and Sabbath School comes in touch with their young lives and is the only hope for their uplift. The teacher must be kind but always firm. His authority must not be impaired or his hold on the children is gone. Let me cite a concrete case. Last Saturday and Sunday it was circulated around East over this Reserve.
that the Department would not allow Wallace to send Jerry Adamseout to Brentford and that the Agent was going to send Wallace away and get another teacher. We have not had a case of turkey for months until this week. No less than six boys played turkey this week, a direct result of above report.

Now allow me to show you how Jerry's friends broke their promise from the moment they tried to get Jerry re-instated into French Bay school. Please do not misunderstand as I never make pretenses. Elijah Adamseout started out with the sole purpose of overruling the Compulsory Law and openly and brazenly bragged that he would do so. I simply said nothing but kept the law after him as he drifted towards the rocks. He was doing the very thing I desired he should do, otherwise I would be compelled to expel Jerry from the school for the sake of the other pupils. The action of the Agent or his friends solemn promises carried out without my knowledge, and without giving a correct and full report to the Department brought, in good faith by the Department, an answer adverse to my plans for
the boys welfare.

Jerry was brought to my school the first morning April 4th at exactly 10 o'clock. I refused to let him take his seat. School had been open one hour. He did not return for the afternoon session. I gave no reason for my refusal to the friend who brought him. The 8 and 9 o'clock bell had been rung. All knew the hour for opening school.

The next morning another friend brought Jerry at exactly 15 minutes after 10 o'clock. This time he came from the home of his aunt who is living in a state of adultery and fornication with the friend who brought Jerry to school. Jerry had about 40 rods to come from this home. Again both bells 8 and 9 rang out. I again refused to allow him to take a seat. He did not come for the afternoon session nor did he come again until May 1st. Another friend brought him the 3rd time. Late as usual. I refused him a seat and he has not been back since.

Elijah Shumaguet or his friends had evidently no intention of fulfilling either the letter or the spirit of the law. The sole object was to override the law in some way. My tenant officer laid the information against Jerry's guardian on October 20th, 1910 over six months ago. Six months lost in Jerry's education.
Jerry is now over 14 years of age. If it takes six months to handle a charge of this kind where the law and regulations are clearly stated and where plain and imperative instructions are given by the Department for the law to be strictly complied with, it seems to me that Jerry will be over school age before the Agent could get another information dealt with.

His friends have now had another chance to act squarely and honestly but have sadly failed. I can prove the charge herein laid by any trust officer who was watching the case carefully and by others as well if necessary.

I have the honor to be respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Teacher
