Dear Sir,

As I will not have time the latter part of next week I take this opportunity of reporting on the conduct of Jerry Ahmuneet for the month of June. I bore with Jerry's conduct and disobedience throughout the month of May in order to avoid any appearance of placing obstacles in the way of him making good his promise of regular attendance at school. His coming in at any hour of the forenoon had demoralized the whole school until no fewer than 16 pupils came in late on the morning of June 2nd, some coming in as late as 20 minutes to 11 o'clock. The thought pressed itself upon me that the department concluded that if it compelled Jerry to attend school I was quite capable of managing him when he did come. In this the department made no mistake so long as I was not interfered with from outside sources. Accordingly, on the evening of Friday June 2nd, I informed the school that beginning on Monday June 5th, I would whip every pupil who was not in his or her place.
place in the school-room when the nine o'clock bell ceased tolling. Moreover I informed Jerry that henceforth every time he failed to have his school work done in proper time and every time I found him interfering with other pupils in the way of keeping them from their work I would punish him severely.

On Monday morning June 5th, Jerry came in late. I made good my promise before I allowed him to take his seat. The next morning June 6th, Jerry came late again. This time I took Solomon's advice Proverbs 14:18. Jerry soon realized he was late for school. This caused Jerry to consider the matter and to such good purpose that he has never been late one solitary morning since nor have I had a single pupil late since June 6th. That is not all. I have had no trouble with him for sickness &c. I have not had to touch him since for any cause. Not one syllable of complaint has reached me from any of his friends touching my treatment of him.

I have a diligent, obedient and punctual pupil in Jerry now and he will come regularly so long as he fears being sent to an Industrial School.

The attendance the week ended last night was
been the best since the second week in May.

There are a few boys who are giving considerable trouble in respect to irregular attendance. It is so near vacation now that it is not worth while taking any action until after the holidays. I find that the fear of being sent to an Industrial School works far better than giving the parents as it touches both pupil and parents and thus directly aids the parent though the Indian parent fails to comprehend this aspect of it.

When the Department gives a parent personal notice of intention to commit to an Industrial School a certain pupil or pupils if not sent to school regularly, unless excused as the Law provides ninety-nine times out of a hundred the trouble ends right there and the so mentioned pupils are sent to school right along after such notice is served. It saves putting the parent to expense as well.

Your humble servant,

[Signature]

Teacher

I beg to inform the department that Jerry Ahnagoguet has not been in school since Christmas. He persistently refuses to attend school. The truant officer has called upon his guardians and friends, who signed the written promise that they would send him regularly, to no purpose. I refused to report him in the December quarter in the hope I could induce him to attend more or less regularly this winter. He did remarkably well in his studies up to December, being about ready to enter the 4th standard. In fact in order to encourage him I promoted him into the 3rd reader just before Christmas intending to give him special and individual attention as far as possible.

I understand Elijah Wahbagon's two boys Peter and Andrew have been committed to an Industrial School. Neither of these two boys have been in school since Christmas. The father was notified of the commitment and informed that if the children were subsequently sent regularly to school, the...
order of commitment would not be pressed. This was done with my approval. Instead of taking advantage of this offer, the parents closed up the house and I am informed went to the vicinity of Paisley. If the Department can find room in any one of our Institutes for these two boys, in my opinion, these two boys should be at once removed from the custody of the parents and placed in an Institute at the earliest possible moment regardless of cost. These boys, especially Peter the elder one, is incorrigible. They will be back in the spring, three months older and more confirmed than ever in their evil habits to sow the seeds of evil in the minds of other children. Just when said Council passed said Resolution I knew not neither did I know that such a Resolution had been passed or the matter of a Inward Officer interfered with until this afternoon.

I take this, my earliest opportunity, in order to protest against the appointment of Thomas Wahbeze as Inward Officer of the Indian School at French Bay for the following reasons viz:

1st. Thomas Wahbeze cannot speak the English Language neither does he understand it when spoken by another, hence as a Inward Officer he is of no use as the teacher cannot communicate with him.

2nd. He was Inward Officer of French Bay School for some time about four years ago or thereabouts.
and his conduct was so detrimental to the best interests of the school that the late Mr. Scofield dismissed him. Every time he entered the schoolroom the teacher was compelled to cease work entirely until he was fit to leave owing to a habit he persisted in of running about the room talking to the pupils in the Indian Language, the confusion rendering work impossible. Both Mr. Scofield and the teacher instructed him not to do this. The Agent, on two different occasions, when complaint was made, sent for him to the school and with the aid of an interpreter gave him full instructions as to his duties the last time warning him that his prompt dismissal would follow any departure from the instructions then given. He still persisted in disobeying the warning and prompt dismissal followed.

3rd, His advanced age renders him entirely unfit to discharge the duties of a Truant Officer.

4th, He is a disagreeable, cantankerous, quarrelsome old man with whom no one can get along. His wife cannot live with him and has been separated from him for some years.

5th, The teacher at French Bay (J.G. Wallace) did his utmost to try and get along with him.
and did put up with him as long as it was possible to endure it; when endurance failed, Mr. Scuffield dismissed him and appointed David Root in his stead. David Root gave good satisfaction until total blindness about 12 months ago rendered him unfit to do the work. Mr. Scuffield and the teacher consulted and Joseph Mitchell was permitted to act as Inward Officer under David Root. The Agent and the teacher agreeing to let the matter so rest until we could ascertain from actual practice as to the wisdom of appointing Joseph Mitchell permanently. Joseph Mitchell has a white man's command of the English Language, is an intelligent, agreeable and active Indian and has proven himself after a long test to be the best Inward Officer I have ever had as yet. He is not treaty but his wife is treaty. Some of the Indians claim that being a non-treaty Indian bars him from holding the Office of Inward Officer. I fail to find this bar in the Indian Act or in the Compulsory Act. Had Mr. Scuffield been aware of what the Council were doing he would not have permitted it for one moment. He knew nothing of it as he was so unused his
son kept all business away from him by his physician's advice. The Indians took advantage of this to get this Resolution slipped quietly through and sanctioned without the Agent's knowledge or mine, knowing full well that the Agent's son, who was doing the business for his poor sick father, would never detect it in time to prevent its sanction by the Department.

For the sake of the school, I humbly beg the Department to appoint Joseph Mitchell as Trust Officer and cancel the appointment of Thomas Wahbeze, as, after a long trial, I, as teacher, cannot get along with Thomas Wahbeze as my Trust Officer for the reasons above given.

Hoping to hear from the Department at its earliest convenience re this matter—I am its humble servant,

J.G. Wallace
Teacher.

Dear Sir;

I have to reply to your letter No31-1-1 of the 2nd inst regarding the conditions of the children at the French Bay School as reported by Nurse Cousins.

I think I might say that I have not been unmindful of these matters, in fact when I came here five years ago I recall going into the subject with Agent Putman, and in my school reports I drew attention to the fact that these people are far from clean. They are much more dirty than the western Indians.

With regard to vaccinating the children, I would say that in 1927 Dr Laird of Southampton arrived at the school and vaccinated those pupils who happened to be present. I believe at the time Agent Putman was under notice of dismissal, for the parents had not been informed, and some resented it. Since then I have had several new pupils, but I have not pressed the vaccination need, apart from telling the parents that they ought to get them done, feeling that the subject might at some time be explained to the people at one of their meetings, which would be better than rousing their resentment to any action that might be taken. Nurse Cousins held a meeting at the Hall, and I expect spoke on the matter, and I also have since spoken to the parents, so that the children, I think, might be done at any time.

With regard to lice and skin trouble, I might say that when this prevails in country schools among white settlers, the usual custom is to send the children home to get cleaned up. Such results in the parents feeling somewhat of the disgrace, and there is an improvement at once; but in the case of Indians here, they have no feeling of disgrace, and very little self respect. If I sent any children home they would simply stop at home for a few days, and take no notice. I am able, however, to impress upon the children the importance of clean hands, faces, and brushed hair, and this is done. In addition to this, I have used some small health posters sent from time to time, as reading lessons, writing exercises, and drawing copies, so that the children have these matters brought to the minds.

I would also like to say that one can do very little with the children along these lines, while their homes are so dirty. My wife and I have been on various reserves since 1911, and have never seen the conditions that prevail among these people. When the children of some families do have new clothes (seldom new) they simply wear them into holes. Some of them sleep in their clothes all winter, and I told that in some cases the women are just too lazy to clean up their homes. I am hopeful that the visits of Nurse Cousins, and the meetings of the Womens Institute will cause some improvement along these lines.

April 11, 1931.

Personal.

Dear Mr Ferrier,

Arising out of my school report, in which I referred to the fencing of these buildings, I have letter No 31-1-1 of 10th inst signed by the Secretary stating owing to small attendance the question of closing the school has been seriously considered and no expenditure can be undertaken at the present time, etc.

I am sorry that it should have been felt necessary to write in this way, because for the past couple of years my school has had a much larger attendance than when we first came here, and as far as I can see will remain a good school for some years to come. At the present time I have an enrolment of 17, with an average age of between 9-10, and more pupils coming on within the next twelve months. I checked back the register for the past nine years, when making up my quarterly report, and found that the past twelve months has been the best during this period. It has so happened however that in the Agent's monthly report, the attendance does not show high, mainly because his morning visits have occurred on dull mornings. This is one of the difficult points with Indian children. On a bright morning their parents are up, and out early, and on dull bad mornings they are not. But the Agent knows we are getting a good turn out for apart from his visits the Attendance officer has called in about twice a month all winter, and so far I have not had to request him to visit the parents.

The children are making good progress. I am aware of this, but some of the parents are also informing me of this fact. We have not been involved in any dispute with the parents over school or any other matter since Mr Putnam left some years ago. Neither have we been with the Agent. As far as I know everything has been going along satisfactorily and there does not seem to be any cause to comment upon the attendance.

Regarding the fence, that is in very poor shape. The Dept. Inspector last fall asked the Agent and myself if anything was to be done as also the school steps, and approaches to the closets. The house also needs shingles. He agreed as to the need, and the Agent and myself felt that it was only proper for us to state these needs. They are not in that condition that would compel us to close owing to lack of funds to repair, but they are in poor shape.

Arising out of the report of Nurse Cousins, I stated "This reserve has no regular Medical officer." I was not aware until today that Dr Volumns of Southampton is our Medical officer. I called at the Agency this afternoon, and this fact happened to be spoken of. The Agent and I have never had any occasion to refer to the subject otherwise I would have heard. As a whole the children are much the same as other Indian pupils; they could be cleaner, and they could be worse.

All things considered I cannot help thinking it would be a mistake to close; there is no doubt that the question of reopening would be brought up by the parents in a very few months.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Ruby Nadjaona

In September, 1925, when I took over, the school had three boys on the roll:

Oliver Kawcishig, Issac Nashkawa, and Percy Stevens, all down as 12 years of age, but more likely getting on for 15.

Oliver, and Issac could read with difficulty, the first reader, and Percy could hardly read the primer. None of them reached the second reader.

May 8, 1931.

Dear Mr Ferrier,

Within the past two weeks, or so, I have received three messages, regarding our work here, hence the need of writing. Agent Robertson told me of your intention of keeping the school open at any rate until June 30, 1932, without any change either regards my position, or repairs.

The Rev. E.F. Bishop of Southampton who called at your office tells me that we had no need to be concerned to any great degree with regards to our employment, and

Mr Inspector MacGowan (I may not have caught his name correctly) told me that, for some years the Department have been entirely dissatisfied with my work, and that unless there was a change, I would have to get out, and in a very few months, at the end of the year in fact.

In answer to my question, "If this went at the end of the coming June, or June 1932?" he did not know.

Having conveyed your message in this manner, he added a great deal more, from which I gathered that Mr Inspector MacCool of Walkerton is the cause of the difficulties.

Mr MacGowan, would listen to no reasoning, but added I was at liberty to take up the manner with you.

I have therefore gone carefully over my school, and enclose a detailed list of what the children can do, together with the last examination that Mr MacCool gave the children as far as I can remember it. In fairness to myself and the children I would ask you to look this over.

I might have informed you in 1926 that Mr MacCool has, from the first inspection given me the impression that he resented your making my appointment here, over his head so to speak. He, I am told, looks upon the appointments of teachers in his district as being something within his powers, and school trustees in French Bay white school, some seven miles down the lake told me that if Mr MacCool likes a teacher whom he has obtained, everything is alright, otherwise it is all wrong. I have been told this on several occasions.

At the last inspection Mr MacCool only took notes of the number in each grade. In the past he has noted details of the work, but this time he did not, was present from 9.40 till 10.55, with 15 children present. It seems to me that his judgement was formed beforehand, which is most unfair.

The statement that no progress has been made has caused me so much astonishment, that I took an unexpected opportunity to obtain the opinion of an entire stranger to myself, and the children, as to this being correct.
The Rev. Father Cadeau, Roman Catholic missionary for this and Cape Croker reserves, called to see me. Throughout Bruce he is well known and spoken of as being well informed upon local Indian matters, and he is one whom I felt that he would at least be fair. I have only met him once before, some years ago at Cape Croker, and then only for a minute or so. Also I should add that the children at this end are not of his faith.

I requested him to examine the school in any manner he saw fit, either in English or Indian, or both, and he stayed with us the whole afternoon.

At four o'clock he informed me that the work, in his judgment was entirely satisfactory, and that I had reason to be proud of the progress and that whoever had informed the Dept. that no progress had been made was very much mistaken.

I did not ask the Rev. Father to inform you this, or if you have any confidence in his judgement I do not know, nor can I say what he might tell you if you should ask. I might also say that Mr MacCool told the children that they were doing very nicely, and gave me no hint as to his dissatisfaction.

Among your instructions to me in 1925, you may recall these. "Do not quarrel, or have discord with the parents if at all possible to avoid it." This has been avoided, but when I pointed this out to Mr MacGowan and that there was general satisfaction among the parents I was told that the Dept. took no notice whatever of the Indians likes or dislikes.

If the Provincial authorities maintain that the Indian children must conform to white standards, as Mr MacGowan claimed, I must state that the conditions under which these people live make such a thing impossible. Mr MacCool informed me some time ago that "he had never been in an Indian house and would not care to go in" thus showing that he knows nothing of their conditions, neither does he appear to grasp the fact that the only English they hear is from myself.

They live on a semi-starvation diet, often come to school without anything to eat at midday, and never more than two pieces of dry bread, and I am disposed to think that the Junior Red Cross would be very much astonished that they can do as much as they can.

They have made progress, and can continue to do so at the present rate, but I feel that the conditions conveyed by Mr MacGowan message (i.e. that there must be a great improvement to satisfy Mr MacCool) cannot be done, for nothing I could do would satisfy Mr MacCool, so I will, with your permission, communicate at once with the Bishop of Saskatchewan, or some other Anglican Bishop in the west with whom I trust you will permit me to undertake future school work.

I must however express regret that we cannot reap the fruits of a good deal of real work in the school here, and that we should be put to the expense of moving, and a general upheaval, a regret, I think too, will be felt by a good many friends we have made during our stay in Bruce.

Yours faithfully,

Ottawa, May 11, 1931.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, with enclosures, reporting on the progress that has been made at the French Bay Indian Day School. I asked Inspector McGookin to inform you that this school, under your management, would be given another year's trial, i.e., to June, 1932, but that the Department expected you would get better results than in the past. It is true that the reports received from the Provincial Inspector and from Indian Affairs officers have been far from satisfactory, and it was my duty to seriously consider either closing the school or arranging for a new incumbent. The present attendance and the prospects for pupils in the early future suggest that the school be kept open, and it has been decided to give you a further trial of one year. Mr. Indian Agent Robertson was so informed on the 23rd ultimo.

The Department hopes that you will bend every energy towards making your school a real success during the next academic year and that the institution will have a general civilizing influence on the reserve.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir -

I hereby respectfully submit, for your careful consideration, my application for the position of teacher on the Indian Reserve at Saugeen, Bruce County, Southampton, Ont.

I have a Permanent First Class Certificate. In addition I have also an Elementary Physical Culture, an Elementary Art, an Elementary Vocal Music Certificate, an Intermediate Agric. Certificate, a Strathcona Grade B. Certificate, and three Religious Instruction Certificates. I have also taken a course in Book-keeping and business management from the L.C.S. schools so as to be qualified to handle the executive duties of a school Principal properly.

I have also the honor to be a graduate of the new Two Year Normal School Course. I have had two years of Professional Training at the Normal School. I have had four years of successful experience as a teacher in Ontario Public Schools. This experience, together with my two years of Professional Training, gives me a very great advantage over the ordinary teacher.

I take a special interest in sports and athletics and in all kinds of school activities. I spend most of my spare time organizing and supervising playground activities. I also take a special interest in the teaching of Agriculture and in beautifying the school grounds by planting trees, shrubs and flowers. I can also guarantee absolute satisfaction in all matters of school management, organization, and Discipline, as well as the highest efficiency in the teaching of the curriculum. Sir:

We will not be definitely aware, until about the middle of August, next, whether there will be sufficient funds to provide the expense of conducting this school. MEMORANDUM:

MR. BUSKARD,

Referring to your memorandum of the 29th ultimo, to which is attached a further communication from Mr. P. H. Gentleman, former teacher of the French Bay Indian Day School, on the Sauguen Reserve, I would state as follows:

Mr. Gentleman is under a misapprehension in regard to his being eligible for superannuation under the Public Service Retirement Act, 1920, better known as the Calder Act. In Section 8 of this Act, as amended, 1923, it is stated: "No person shall be retired under the provisions of this Act after the first day of July, 1924." This Act expired on that date, being superseded by the present Superannuation Act, which went into effect as from July 19, 1924. Under the Calder Act, it was not required that contributions be made by the person retired. Three teachers, who had lengthy service, were retired under its provisions, although they had made no contribution to the Superannuation Fund during their period of service. Under the present Act, it is required that five per cent. of salary of permanent employees be contributed.

Teachers in Indian day schools are exempt from the operation of the provisions of the Civil Service Act in so far as the principle of competition in the matter of appointment is concerned and are therefore classed as "temporary" civil servants. Only permanent civil servants are eligible for superannuation. Contributions to the Superannuation Fund cannot be accepted

- in the case
in the case of temporary civil servants, and, since the going out of force of the Calder Act, there is no provision for superannuation or pension to teachers of Indian schools.

Regarding Mr. Gentleman's assertion that, upon his first appointment as teacher, he was informed by the late Honourable David Laird and Mr. Graham, former Indian Commissioners, that he would be entitled to pension, I would say both these former officials were well aware that no provision was made for the superannuation of teachers. Mr. Gentleman has never contributed to any superannuation or pension fund, and there is no Act or Regulation now in force under which he could be granted superannuation.

With reference to the reasons for dispensing with Mr. Gentleman's services, I would refer you to memorandum dated June 27th, last, embodying the reports of Mr. Inspector McCookin and Mr. J. M. Gane, Provincial Public School Inspector.

I am enclosing, for the Minister's signature, a draft reply to Mr. Gentleman and am also returning herewith his letter, as requested.

In my opinion it will serve no purpose to continue correspondence with Mr. Gentleman. The Department's position, regarding his dismissal and his claim for superannuation, has been fully explained to him, and I would respectfully suggest that the matter be considered closed. From our past experience with him, he is a "prolific letter writer".

Dear Sir:—

It has been drawn to my attention that there will be an immediate opening for a teacher in the French Bay Indian School on the Saugeen Indian Reserve. During the past three and a half years I have been the School Inspector visiting this school and I have taken it upon myself to draw this impending vacancy to the attention of one of my former pupils, Mr. Armour Irwin, who is now seeking a position as teacher.

I have known Mr. Irwin for fifteen years—in fact I was his teacher during the last two years of his public school career (1920-1922), and I came to know him quite intimately. Always I found him to be reliable, studious and thoroughly conscientious. Just before he obtained his High School Entrance certificate I took him aside and advised him to direct himself to the teaching profession because I considered that he was of the right calibre for that work. Economic factors prevented Mr. Irwin from finishing his High School course at that time, but he never forgot my advice. After a number of years in other work he returned to High School after which he attended
Normal School (term 1934-1935). His work at the Normal School was brilliant as was shown by the fact that he was not required to write any of the final examinations.

Since Mr. Irwin was my pupil I have been more or less in touch with him and his career. He is now married and has two children. I have never had any occasion to change my opinion formed years ago concerning his excellent character. His presence in any community, white or Indian, would be a real asset. Moreover I have not the slightest doubt that he will make a success of his teaching career if conscientious endeavour can make it possible.

It might be worth while to add that Mr. Irwin, who now resides at 963 Ossington Avenue, Toronto, has been on relief for several years. During this time he finished his High School Course and attended Normal School under most difficult conditions because of the fact that for one, two or three days each week, (including Saturday-by special arrangement), he was engaged in relief work. Industry and ambition such as this require no comment.

I quite believe that the Department of Indian Affairs would make no mistake in engaging this estimable young man as a teacher in French Bay Indian School.

Yours very truly,

J.M. Game

MEMORANDUM:

The Honorable the Superintendent General,

With reference to your memorandum of the 13th instant, regarding the dismissal, from the teaching service of this Department, of Mr. P. H. Gentleman, I beg to say that he was appointed teacher of the French Bay Indian Day School (Saugeen Reserve No. 29 - Electoral District of Bruce North), on October first, 1925, and his services were dispensed with as from June 30th, 1933.

The reports received from the Public School Inspector who visited this school during the period of his service showed that very little progress was being made. Mr. McCookin, Inspector of Indian Agencies, who visited the school in June, 1933, stated as follows:

"I have no hesitation in recommending a change of teacher at this school. I have done so in each report since 1929. The pupils are backward and compare unfavorably with the other two reserve day schools. There is an atmosphere of lifelessness and indolence about the whole classroom. The parents, in some cases, have changed their residence to allow the children to attend one of the two other schools on the reserve. This school is no credit to the Department."

In view of the adverse reports received regarding the work that was performed by Mr. Gentleman, the Department informed him that his services would not be required after the end of the academic year June 30, 1933. In consideration of his length of service, he was granted a retiring allowance equal to two months' salary.

I may say that, since Mr. Gentleman left this school, he has, on many occasions, written the former Minister, the Department and other parties, regarding his dismissal and requesting reinstatement. I might add that Mr. Gentleman's services were dispensed with solely on his record, and the Department cannot recommend his re-engagement in the Indian school service.

Dear Sir:

The morning paper reports your intention of going to Ottawa towards the end of the week, and if this should be correct I am taking the liberty of bringing the following to your notice, which may be of some help to you in dealing with Dominion authorities.

As briefly as possible - I have been in the employ of the Indian Department for some years. First in 1905, at the instance of Commissioner Hon. David Laird, who promised me promotion and a pension at the end of twenty years service, and later from 1911 till 1933, nearly 27 years, as school teacher and reserve overseer. Promises were repeated in 1912 by Mr. Inspector Chisholm, Mr. Commissioner Graham in 1919, and by the late Mr. R. T. Ferrier, Supt. of Indian Education in Ottawa in 1925, who also told me that pensions for Indian school teachers had been done away with, but that as the promise was made, when the time came to retire, we would be taken care of; my wife also being on the staff.

In 1933, while in Ontario, I was discharged for no reason, and given a bonus of two months' salary.

In 1919, during the post office strike, or right after, our salary was doubled, as civil servants. In 1930, when all Dominion employees' salary was cut 10%, we also received the cut as civil servants. Our salary during this period has been on an average of $700 a year, and we have served in remote places in the western provinces and Ontario, spending over $4000 in expenses of moving, fixing departmental buildings and other items in connection with the schools. In my last school in Ontario the man who held the position a year before I was appointed was pensioned on $300 a year after 23 years' service.

We came to British Columbia in 1933, expecting to receive the retiring allowance, I can assure you long looked forward to. But owing to the attitude the Dominion Government has taken towards us, I have had to use my savings and my life insurance which has just about come to an end, and I shall in a couple of months have
to apply to your Relief Department for assistance. I am over fifty years of age, my wife over sixty.

On my dismissal, I took up the subject with the Members of Parliament for the County of Bruce. Nothing could be done. Mr. R. T. Murphy knew nothing about it. Some friends in Victoria wrote to Mr. Bennett, with the same result.

I have a letter from the Prime Minister agreeing to the following request I made to him on the matter:

"If an authority, or commission of any kind can hear my case in Victoria, I will abide by any decision reached provided that such an authority does not consist of officials of the Indian Department."

The Prime Minister agreed to this in a kind of a way after the election, but all I can get now from Ottawa is a letter from a Departmental Secretary saying "contents of my letter is noted."

I would have liked to have an interview with you regarding this subject, as it is clearly one case that is Dominion responsibility. We have lived on Dominion lands (Indian Reserves) for nearly 27 years.

Believe me, my dear Sir,

Yours faithfully,

"P. H. Gentleman"

Re: Mr. P. H. Gentleman

Dear Mr. Chambers:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 18th and also copy of a communication received by you from Mr. J. T. Gawthrop, attached thereto.

I can only state that Mr. Gentleman's claims for re-employment or for a superannuation allowance were carefully reviewed by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs and by the departmental officials, immediately following his dismissal on June 30th, 1933. It was pointed out to Mr. Gentleman at that time that he had not been a member of the permanent Civil Service staff, nor had he at any time contributed to a superannuation fund, and consequently he had no claim for superannuation allowance. The decision was reached that Mr. Gentleman's request for re-employment could not be seriously entertained, in view of the unsatisfactory service he had been rendering over a period of years. The departmental files indicate that, if Mr. Gentleman had made any attempt whatever to follow the Inspectors' instructions during the last five years he was employed with the Department, or if he had made even a partial attempt to keep his school clean and in a sanitary condition, he would still be employed in an Indian day school.

This man steadfastly and persistently refused to accept advice from the Provincial School Inspector, the Indian Agent and the departmental Inspector for Ontario. Mr. Gentleman's letters indicate that he was always

Alan Chambers, Esq.,
National Employment Commission,
Jackson Building,
Ottawa.
always right - the departmental officials always wrong. Mr. Gentleman was, naturally, disappointed at the refusal of the Department to consider his claims, with the result that he appealed again for reconsideration of his case. The files indicate that a very thorough enquiry was again instituted, in respect to his service with the Department and the reasons for dismissal, but the first decision was in no sense modified.

Immediately following the return to power of the present administration, Mr. Gentleman appealed to the Department, on the grounds that he had been unfairly dealt with. His case was again considered, the facts carefully reviewed, the departmental officials consulted and a decision reached that, in view of all the circumstances, Mr. Gentleman had no claim whatever on the Department. In this connection I note that Mr. Gawthrop visited the Department of Indian Affairs on July 24th, last, and interviewed the Departmental Solicitor and the Chief of the Schools Branch on behalf of Mr. Gentleman. At that time, Mr. Gawthrop received a full explanation of Mr. Gentleman's case and the reasons that led to his dismissal.

The fourth paragraph of Mr. Gawthrop's letter, in which he refers to certain physical disabilities from which Mr. Gentleman is now suffering, is, in my judgment, worthy of comment. It is significant that Mr. Gentleman, when writing to the Department in August, 1925, from Leigh on Sea, Essex, England, where he was holidaying at that time, intimated: "I would also say that on reaching England I placed my wife in the hands of one of the best medical men in London, who is attached to two of the largest missionary societies, and was informed that she had a very weak heart and required at least three months' rest."

I think it is only fair to the Department and to the departmental officials that these facts should be known to you. May I further suggest that, if the time at your disposal will enable you to do so, you should call

at the Schools Branch and glance over the file on this case. If you do this, I feel confident you will be satisfied that the Department did not at any time treat this man harshly or unfairly but that he was kept in charge of schools for a number of years, largely on compassionate grounds, despite frequent requests for his dismissal from the field officials.

Yours sincerely,

W. J. F. Pratt,
Secretary.

Gentleman, that he had spent thousands of dollars during his period of service with the Department of Indian Affairs, on the understanding that these expenditures were made with the consent and approval of the Superintendent General and that he (Mr. Gentleman) would be reimbursed for the expenditures he had made.

I may state, by way of comment, that, immediately following a notice of dismissal received by Mr. Gentleman from the Department, early in June, 1933, he communicated with the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs in a letter dated June 6th, 1933. In this letter, Mr. Gentleman intimated that, over a period of years, he had spent "$818 in moving expenses; $185 in other travelling expenses; $337 on repairs to departmental buildings; $442 on Christmas tree prizes; $127 in sports day prizes; $225 in kindergarten school material and music supplies; $407 on relief to destitute Indians (not including free meals and things given from his house for sick women and children); and various odd amounts totalling $664".

Mr. Gentleman did not claim, in this letter, that these expenditures had been authorized by the Department, nor did he claim that he should be reimbursed for the expenditures made by him. His contention was that, in view of his generosity, he had a strong claim on the Government

for a superannuation allowance.

The Department has never at any time made an allowance to Indian day school teachers in lieu of travelling expenses. Supplies for Indian day schools are purchased by the Department, after they are authorized by Indian agents. There is not on file in the Department a vestige of evidence to indicate that Mr. Gentleman spent money on the repair of departmental buildings at any time, nor was it necessary that he should do so. Re: P. H. Gentleman.

Dear Mr. Taylor:

I am instructed by the Minister to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 2nd, in which you ask that the claims of Mr. P. H. Gentleman, formerly employed as a teacher in Indian day schools, be sympathetically reconsidered.

I may state that Mr. Gentleman's claims for re-employment or for a superannuation allowance were carefully and sympathetically reviewed by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs and by the departmental officials, immediately following his dismissal on June 30, 1933. It was pointed out to Mr. Gentleman at that time that he had not been a member of the permanent Civil Service staff, nor had he at any time contributed to a superannuation fund and consequently had no claim for superannuation allowance. The decision was reached that Mr. Gentleman's request for re-employment could not be seriously entertained, in view of the unsatisfactory service he had been rendering the Department over a period of years. The departmental files indicate that, if Mr. Gentleman had made any attempt whatever to follow the Inspectors' instructions during the last five years he was employed by the Department, or if he had made even a partial attempt to keep his school clean and in a sanitary condition, he would still be employed as a teacher in an Indian day school.

This man steadfastly and persistently refused to accept advice from the Provincial School Inspector, the Indian Agent and the departmental Inspector for Ontario. Mr. Gentleman was, naturally, disappointed at the refusal

J. S. Taylor, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ont.
of the Department to recognize his claims, with the result that he appealed again for reconsideration of his case. The files indicate that a very thorough enquiry was again instituted, in respect to his service with the Department and the reasons for his dismissal, but the first decision was in no sense modified.

Immediately following the return to power of the present administration, Mr. Gentleman appealed to the Department on the grounds that he had been unfairly dealt with and that certain promises made to him had been broken. His case was again considered, the facts carefully reviewed, the departmental officials consulted, and a decision reached that, in view of all the circumstances, Mr. Gentleman had no claim whatever on the Department. In this connection I may state that Mr. Gathrop, representing Mr. Gentleman, visited the Department of Indian Affairs on July 24th, last, and interviewed the departmental Solicitor and the Chief of the Schools Branch. At that time Mr. Gathrop received a full explanation of Mr. Gentleman's case and the reasons that led to his dismissal.

I have been unable to discover anything that would indicate that this man has been treated harshly or unfairly by the Department. As a matter of fact, the file indicates that he was kept in charge of schools for a number of years largely on compassionate grounds and in the hope that he would become more interested in his work, despite frequent and persistent requests for his dismissal from the field officials.

In view of these facts and others that might be submitted, I cannot think of any way whereby this case can be reopened and Mr. Gentleman's claim for work or for an allowance considered at this date.

Yours sincerely,

W. J. F. Pratt,
Secretary.

MEMORANDUM:

The Deputy Minister,

Re: P. H. Gentleman
Victoria, B.C.

I am returning herewith correspondence attached to Mr. Pratt's memorandum of September 24th. It is somewhat difficult to supply additional information regarding the dismissal of Mr. Gentleman from the French Bay Indian Day School, in view of the large number of memoranda already sent forward with respect to the service of this man with the Department and the reasons for his dismissal.

It would appear, from the information contained in the second last paragraph of Mr. Gentleman's letter to Mr. Gathrop, that the departmental officials became dissatisfied with this teacher's work as far back as 1915. Mr. Gentleman at that time and since then seems to be obsessed with the thought that the officials, for some reason or other that he does not explain, were prejudiced against him and entered into a conspiracy to have him removed from the school in which he was then teaching. It is altogether likely that the Anglican Church authorities and the departmental officials, when they transferred Mr. Gentleman to an Indian day school in the province of Ontario, did so in the hope that his work under new officials and in new surroundings might prove more satisfactory. The records indicate, however,
that, just as soon as he took up his duties in Ontario, the old obsession still remained with him - that the officials were critical of his work, seeking to persecute him and for some reason or other seeking his dismissal. It is perhaps unfortunate that this man clings so tenaciously to imaginary grievances that seem to have multiplied from year to year. It would be too much to hope that any explanation sent forward to him by the Department or made to his friends would tend in any way to change his attitude.

Mr. Gentleman was never, in my judgment, qualified to teach in an Indian day school. He was employed, however, at a time when fully qualified teachers were exceedingly difficult to secure. It is just possible that a mistake was made by both the departmental officials and the church authorities in continuing him as a teacher when his unfitness was emphasized from time to time by Indian Agents and by Inspectors responsible for the inspection of his schools. I am inclined to think that he was kept for a number of years largely on compassionate grounds.

Director.

Dear Sir:

Before the recent by election I wrote to you calling your attention to the fact that my wife and I had been discharged by the late Bennett Government after many years service in the Indian Department, and that the present Government show no disposition to give us any opportunity to answer the charges brought against us.

In 1905 I was promised promotion and a pension by the late Hon. David Laird, Indian Commissioner at Winnipeg, and in 1933 I was dismissed without reason and given a bonus of two months salary, and have only recently been informed that under the Calder Act of 1924 we are not entitled to the pension. Doubtless this is correct.

However, every once in awhile one comes across such items in the paper, such as I have clipped this evening, and which I am taking the liberty of enclosing.

It would appear that these men were appointed to their positions in 1933 at a salary of $10,000 a year and are provided with a pension of $2500 after five years work. I expect too, they were provided with a comfortable office in Ottawa in which to do their work. In contrast to this I started working for the Dominion Government in 1905 at a salary of $300 a year, and my retiring allowance in 1933 was just $180 compelling us to go on relief. Our work too was not in a comfortable office, far from it.

It does not seem to have occurred to any Government at Ottawa that we have long since past the days when Political activity was rewarded with high salaries and large pensions, while those at the foot of the scale are just cast adrift in their old age. Such customs prevailed I believe in 1838, but it does not seem that official Ottawa has advanced much since.

I trust you will understand that it is only by calling the attention of such things to Members of Parliament that any improvements can be obtained.

Yours faithfully,

(SGD) P. W. GENTLEMAN

Dear Mr. Mayhew:

I am in receipt of your letter of May 16 enclosing copy of letter received from Mr. P. W. Gentleman, former teacher of the French Bay Indian Day School.

While Mr. Gentleman did not possess the requisite qualifications for teaching in an Ontario school we employed him as long as his services were considered satisfactory. However, it was decided that it would be in the best interests of the pupils to make a change in the teaching services of this school and we, therefore, dispensed with Mr. Gentleman's services at the end of June, 1933.

Teachers of Indian Day Schools do not contribute to superannuation fund and do not come under its provisions in any manner. The majority of Indian Day School teachers only remain in the work for a comparatively short time. In the few cases where teachers have been employed for several years we allow a gratuity of two months' salary on retirement. This payment was made to Mr. Gentleman at the time he was dismissed in 1933.

Yours truly,

To the Rural School Secretaries:

There is a very definite shortage of teachers and this condition will probably continue throughout the period of the war and possibly for some time afterwards. In this Inspectorate at the present time there are 23 married women engaged as teachers. They are all qualified but under normal circumstances would not have returned to the profession. Five School Boards even found it necessary to engage teachers who had been granted Temporary Permits by the Department of Education for one year only. Contracts must not be signed with the latter teachers again before advertising several times for qualified teachers in a newspaper with a more or less province-wide circulation (e.g., The Globe and Mail). If this brings no results consult your local inspector who, if necessary, will recommend that Temporary Permits be granted to suitable persons.

School Boards would be well advised not to dispense with the services of teachers who are giving satisfactory service as they are not easily replaced. However, if a contract is to be terminated the Board should notify the teacher to this effect, in writing, before June 1st. When engaging experienced teachers it always advisable to obtain confidential statements from their former inspectors.

Inquiries from teachers concerning vacancies come to my office at this time of year but I do not always know which schools require teachers. School Secretaries could frequently be put in touch with prospective teachers more readily if they advised this office promptly of their needs.

It might be of some assistance when considering the salary of your teacher for 1943-44 to know the present trend of salaries. Below is a list of the average salaries paid to rural teachers in this Inspectorate at the beginning of each school year since 1931.

| Year | Salary |
|------|--------|
| 1931 | $915   |
| 1932 | $614   |
| 1933 | $664   |
| 1934 | $625   |
| 1935 | $601   |
| 1936 | $623   |
| 1937 | $654   |
| 1938 | $704   |
| 1939 | $753   |
| 1940 | $768   |
| 1941 | $837   |
| 1942 | $955   |

From this it is apparent that salaries are definitely on the up-grade. The average for the coming year will probably be $1,000 or over. Several School Boards are now paying $1,100. If a new teacher is required, the earlier the Board advertises the less likelihood there is of difficulty in obtaining the services of one.

A questionnaire concerning your teacher for next year is enclosed. Contract forms will be mailed to each secretary this month.

Yours very truly,

J.M. Game, I.P.S.

"There are not many pupils and since many of my belongings are in Manitoba, I would like to return to that province under your Department."

If Miss Dean has not already discussed the above matter with you, you should interview her at once and let us have a report at the earliest possible date. It is hoped that Miss Dean will continue in charge of the school until at least the end of December."
I have noted particularly Miss Dean's statement that there are not many pupils. Are all the children who should attend this school attending regularly? If not, you should take immediate action to see that they do so.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Neary:

After receiving your letter regarding the French Bay Indian School, I wrote to the agent there for some information. His reply was rather vague & discouraging. He stated that the residence was partly furnished but didn't say what that included. He also said the school was five mile from the highway but didn't give anything further in that line either. By the time I would hear from him again so much time would have elapsed. I feel that I should dismiss the matter and allow you & contact other teachers. I know it is important & have the vacancy filled at once and I would rather not delay you longer.

Although I was very interested when I heard of this vacancy I had decided to await further news from the Malpole Island School. I am hoping that my application for that position may be favourably considered in the near future. I have written &
Hi. Stallwood there, at the same time I sent in my application.

I would have liked to be at Chippewa Hill but feel that it is quite a gamble & accept the position without more information. Of the five miles & the highway is closed all winter it would eliminate the possibility of my husband getting to work, and he had planned to find employment near there as soon as we were settled & he had rested a month or so.

I trust that I have not inconvenienced you but I have written promptly & your to Mr. Robertson on Oct. 30th.

Thanking you very sincerely for contacting me about this school.

Yours respectfully,

Bertha H. Anderson

Southampton, Ont. March 21, 1923.

Mr. J.J. Wallace, school teacher, Saugeen Indian Reserve has had a recent attack of Pleurisy from which he is slowly convalescing.

He has been suffering for years from chronic bronchitis and asthma. He has had two attacks of Pneumonia in the last twelve years and three attacks of Pleurisy in the last three years. Ottawa, September 3rd, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, tendering your resignation as teacher of the French Bay School on the Saugeen Reserve to take effect at the end of the present month.

In reply I beg to say that the circumstances under which you find it necessary to terminate your services have been noted, and your resignation is accepted. Before leaving, you should prepare and hand to the local Indian Agent your quarterly return showing the attendance, days taught, etc., and he will forward the same to the department, when payment of salary and bonus due you to the end of the present month will be made.

An application has been received from Harvey Lindsay to succeed you as teacher. We would prefer a teacher having higher qualifications, and we are requesting the Public School Inspector, Mr. McCool, to nominate the services of a qualified teacher. In the event, however, of his being unable to do so, the application of Mr. Lindsay will receive consideration.

We are informing Mr. Agent Putnam of your resignation and the date on which same will take effect.

Your obedient servant,

Upon receipt of notice concerning their arrival, you should make arrangements to accept shipment and arrange for storage either in Southampton or at the teacher's residence. February 13, 1920.

Dear Mr Ferrier,

I have a half yearly premium on an insurance policy due on the 29th of this month, which I am unable to meet.

I have always understood that I have 30 days grace in which to make payment, and I intended taking care of this out of my March salary, but the 30 days would expire just before I would receive this cheque, and I wrote to the company to ask for an extension of time. The enclosed is their reply, from which I gather they require $10.34 for this privilege. I have never been behind in these payments, and the old loan mentioned I can take care of in September as the purpose for which this loan was made me in 1925 is returnable this year.

I am making quarterly payments to London, but our expenses this time last year with Owen Sound Hospital, put me back all the year, and I had to manage a loan at the Bank for the September quarter, which I have just settled, and of course I don't want to fall down on the policy.

Under these circumstances could you make us an advance of $100 on our present quarters salary, or rather have this amount placed to my credit at the Bank of Commerce Southampton by Saturday the 25th, which would enable me to have this payment on hand at Winnipeg by the 29th.

I am not entirely certain about the 30 days grace, but I think this is stated in the policy. The company however are holding the policy on the loan, which was originally $500. The loan interest I paid last year in August in a lump sum.

I hope you will be able to make me an advance. I do not like to ask the Bank for another loan so early. It would cost much less than $10.34 if it becomes necessary, but I want to avoid it if it is possible to do so. Please let me have the attached back again.

Yours faithfully,

P.W. Eastman

R.T. Ferrier, Esq.
Dept. Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Ottawa, December 30, 1933.

Madam:

I have to inform you that the Department will be pleased to approve of your appointment as teacher of the French Bay Indian Day School, on the Saugeen reserve, near Southampton, Ont., as from the first proximo. The salary allowed will be at the rate of $80 per teaching month, less 10%.

The Department understands that you have a second class Ontario certificate. The local Indian Agent is Mr. Don Robertson, Chippawa Hill, Ont. I would request that you communicate with him and inform him definitely of the date on which you will be prepared to commence duties, which, it is hoped, will be on or about the third proximo, the date the schools re-open after the present Christmas holidays.

There is a teacher's residence in connection with this school, where you may reside. Mr. Robertson will give you full information regarding the residence or the obtaining of boarding accommodation. He is also being instructed to arrange with you for the preparing and forwarding of a requisition for any classroom equipment and furnishings for the residence, if required.

We understand there are some 12 children who could attend this school. It is hoped that you will meet with every success in the work. I would request that you immediately communicate with Mr. Robertson, informing him of the date you will begin duties.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Miss Winnifred Stead,
C/o W. J. Stead,
Wiarton, Ont.

Ottawa, November 5th, 1935.

Sir,-

With reference to the employment of Mrs. A. Martin (nee Miss Winnifred A. Stead) as teacher of the French Bay Indian Day School, I beg to direct your attention to Section 36 (1) of the Civil Service Regulations, which provides as follows:

(1) "Hereafter, no married woman, whose husband is living, shall be eligible for appointment in the public service;

(2) "Provided that, when the supply of experienced help for any particular kind of work is not sufficient to meet the demands of the public service, a married woman may be certified for temporary employment;

(3) "Where it can be established by a married woman that her husband is unable, through illness or other cause, to contribute to her support, such married woman may be certified for permanent or temporary appointment."

In the public service, when a woman marries, she is required, under the regulations, to resign her position. It is, therefore, necessary to dispense with Miss Stead's services and you should, therefore, advise her that her employment as teacher of the French Bay Indian Day School will terminate when the school closes for the Christmas holidays.

You will be advised later regarding the name and qualifications of the teacher whom the Department has decided to place in charge of this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

D. Robertson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippawa Hill, Ont.

To the Secretary-

Ottawa 15th August 1901-

I beg to report that during my recent visit at the Sauguen Indian Reserve, I examined the stable erected for the teacher at French Bay, about which complaint was made to the Deputy Minister, and found it completed in accordance with the specification. It was not quite finished until after my arrival at the Reserve, when the Agent told me he had instructed Henry Ritchie, the Contractor, to have it finished, as I was going to inspect it.

The teacher was absent from home and the door of the stable was locked, but I had a view of the inside through the window. I measured the dimensions and found them correct, and I made an estimate of the work, which after making what I consider ample allowance for everything, including workmanship, I found to be $102.58. The actual cost paid Ritchie is $118.50

In this connection, I may state that the Rev. W.B. Danard, in a communication to the Minister last Month, on File 59273/2, states that the Teacher at French Bay told him that he had to beard Henry Ritchie and to furnish the hinges for the doors in order to get it built, and that he got no pay for the same, and also that Ritchie built it as he thought best, it being left to him to do so by the Agent.

Owing to the Teacher's absence, I am unable to verify this, but if it is true, the Agent should have made Ritchie pay for his beard and also the hinges, as the contract price included the whole work.

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of 28th ultimo -153978- in which you ask for an opinion as to whether under section 36 of the Public Works Act tenders received must be submitted to the Governor-in-Council in cases in which an agent of the department obtains prices for work, verbally or in writing, to be performed on Indian reserves and to be paid out of Indian funds or money not specially voted for that purpose. As a case in point you instance two closets which are required at an Indian school and in connection with which your agent has received two offers from responsible builders to put them up for stated sums.

In reply I beg to state that in my opinion whenever tenders are invited those received must be submitted to the Governor-in-Council before the contract is awarded, and that, whether the invitation is by advertisement or otherwise.

Where it is inconvenient to go to Council with tenders and the work comes within the definition of paragraph (c) of section 36 it is competent to the Minister to deal with the case under that paragraph.

It does not, I think, as a matter of law, make any difference that the payment for the work will be made from the interest money of the band in the instance to which you refer.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Deputy Superintendent General

of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, July 23, 1906.

The Acting Deputy Minister,

On March 19 Mr. Agent Scoffield was asked to obtain an estimate of the cost of erecting new closets for the French Bay and Scotch Settlement schools in accordance with the plans and specifications sent him. The Agent submitted the plans to builders and received two offers, one from an Indian of the band for the sum of $131.00, and another offer from the Chippawa Lumber Company for $130.00.

You will see there is only $1 difference and from the Agent's letter it would appear that he considers the Indian as competent to carry out the work.

As there was some doubt as to the application of Sec. 36, Chap. 39 An Act respecting the Public Works of Canada Revised Statutes '06 to this case, the Department of Justice was asked for its opinion and on the 11th inst. it replied that it was of opinion whenever tenders are invited those received must be submitted to the Governor in Council before the contract is awarded, whether the invitation is by advertisement or otherwise. In view of this opinion these tenders should be submitted to Council, but I think in the memorandum it would be only fair to state that one of the tenderers is an Indian and that he is competent to perform the work satisfactorily, the difference being so slight I think he should get the preference.

Sir:

I have the honor to state that a large number of wells in this vicinity has gone dry since the hard frost. There has not been much rain since before harvest, and the supply of water has gradually got less in a number of wells. At the Scotch settlement there is hardly enough to supply the pupils and teachers family.

At French Bay School the well has failed to supply a sufficient quantity for three weeks or a month, and the last two weeks the well has been and is dry. The teacher has to carry all the water for the use of his family over a quarter of a mile. He notified me last Saturday that if I did not get a supply of water he would close the school.

I was thinking that if we got a thaw in January the water would again return to the wells, but we are not likely to get a thaw or rain for some time now, and I hardly know what to advise the Dept. to do.

The new crib that was put in this well in 1935 had to be made about 4" smaller so that it could go down inside the old crib. If I tried to deepen the well, there would have to be a new crib started from the bottom 4" smaller than the present one, which would be too small for a man to work inside. The quicksand comes in so rapidly, we cannot deepen the well without cribbing it.

This leaves

Chippewa Hill, April 24th, 1909.

Indian Agent Chippewa Hill, Ont.

Dear Sir,

As you are aware, I notified you personally on the 14th current month, that a portion of the fence surrounding the teacher's lot at French Bay was wrecked by age, decay and the wind, leaving the property an open commons. The posts are rotted off, the lumber decayed, and useless on two sides south and east. In order to allow of a crop this season prompt action is a necessity, as seed-time is already here. There will be required new posts, new lumber (otherwise wire) besides the expenses of labor in connection therewith and nails as well. You instructed me "to toggle this up for myself as you had done with yours." This I must refuse to do, as I do not consider it any part of my duty to keep in repair, at my own expense, public properties on the Reserve. A portion of the fence is entirely wrecked, the balance of the two sides mentioned above remain standing on props, and has been in this condition over three years. I have kept this fence in repair for over eight years at my own expense for nails and labor. It is so decayed I cannot do it now as having but one hand, I cannot do the labor.

Sincerely yours,

J.J. Wallace

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that the Physiology wanted by me reached me in good condition. Contents included circulars, etc. Shall follow your instructions to the best of my ability. Have been giving attention to this subject all along.

Doing a little with the Catechismics. Have small ventilating fan. Shall give it full attention as soon as the season will permit of outside exercises.

The ventilation and the seating of my school-room at French Bay require immediate attention; a number of the seats are broken and I cannot seat all my pupils at times. New and modern seats should be installed as early as possible, single seats. The windows should be weighted so as to be easily raised at the bottom and lowered from the top as no other system could very well be installed here. I am convinced it was owing to the restricted air of my school-room that I fell a prey to Pneumonia on December 8th last. Pupils complain continually of head-ache. Two pupils left the school-room sick and are dead. As it is the school is in winter a pest hole and if not improved I shall, for the sake of my own life, be compelled to seek employment elsewhere. Your humble servant,

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform the Department, that owing to the large attendance of pupils at this school at present and for some time past I cannot seat comfortably all the pupils. I have seating capacity for 28 pupils, 14 boys and 14 girls. I have on my roll 32 pupils and two or three others who ought to be here. On the Roll I have 17 boys and 15 girls, so you will readily understand my difficulty. My average for the month of April is 28, my average for last week is 30.4.

I also beg to draw the attention of the Department to the fact that in the event of the Department placing new single chairs or new seats of any kind in this school-room a new floor is an absolute necessity. The portion of the floor upon which the chairs and desks would sit is worn out. Originally a pine floor, under the seats where the children's feet rest is worn in places almost through but the pine knots in the floor did not wear, hence the old floor is so uneven that to place chairs and desks with any degree of regularity or solidity, would be practically impossible. More over, in tearing up the old seats, many of which
are laid down by nails other than screw-nails, the old pine floor will of necessity receive more or less damage generally more. Will the Department pardon me if I offer a suggestion? To my mind, the proper thing to do would be to lay a new hard-wood floor over the entire room on top of the old one provided this is practicable. The room is very cold on wintry days in winter, and hence very uncomfortable and unhealthy for both teacher and pupils. The present floor is a single one and the ventilators (broken) being open renders the floor so cold that the feet are always cold. The double floor would largely remedy this defect. There has been a most excellent hard-wood single floor placed up the centre some few years ago I think probably five years ago.

I am seating the pupils three in a seat at present. This I shall endeavour to get along with until the approaching mid-summer vacation and I hope the Department will then see that new single chairs and desks are installed in order to facilitate my work here and relieve the overcrowding.

Sincerely yours,

J. J. Wallace
Teacher.

Referring to your letter of March 10th, last, in regard to the lack of ventilation in the French Bay school I beg to say that the Department would like you to consult a reliable builder with a view to having the windows fixed so that they will raise and lower properly. It is possible that this might be made effective by the use of chains or tape instead of rope, unless the trouble is with the pocket in which case it might be necessary to make alterations to the frame and pulleys, or it might be that a thin interfering strip is required, but a competent mechanic will no doubt be able to make some suggestions.

At the same time you should obtain an estimate of the cost of laying a hardwood floor.

In order to provide further for ventilation the Department thinks it would be well to have two tin, zinc, or galvanized iron pipes of sufficient size to allow air to be changed three times an hour (the ducts being about nine inches by twelve inches) extending on opposite sides from near the floor, connecting below with the class-room and running up through the ceiling beside the chimney, and so placed as to be well heated. Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith a copy of Jas. McKenzie's report regarding the Scotch Settlement at French Bay Schools, Sauguenay Reserve.

I would inform the Dept. that when the contract was let, it was the intention to lay a new floor on top of the old one; to do so we would have to lay half-inch strips on the old floor—which would cause a vacancy between the floors where dust & vermin would lodge causing an unsanitary condition. We therefore left the hardwood floor already laid in the aisle, a few years ago, which was good, and we laid a new hardwood floor to match it in the rest of the room. It made a good job and saved $18. The rest of the work is done according to contract and is also very satisfactory.

The windows & ventilators work easy & the teacher at French Bay has expressed himself as being well satisfied.

The contract is all completed with the exception of 14 desks at the Bay School. Some of the castings of these desks & seats were broken as reported to the Dept., and I have written 3 times, telephoned once to John B. Smider asking him to replace them.

Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs

I would recommend the Dept. to authorize me to send these boys to Manley school also to advance the expense of sending them which will be about $30 or thirty dollars and for which I herewith enclose vouchers.

You should take the necessary steps to have the ceiling repaired. At any point where the plaster is broken and likely to fall it should be removed and replastered. You should have this work done as cheaply as possible and it should be performed during the coming summer holidays.

Mr. McPharlin states that the teacher's house is badly in need of a coat of paint.

I have to request that you will be good enough to forward a report as to the cost of having the painting done. You should state the quantity of paint that would be required and the cost of the labour in having the painting done. If possible, you should obtain a price from several men competent to do this work and submit the prices received for the consideration of the Department. You should furnish these prices as soon as possible, in order that, if it is decided to have the work done, it can be carried out during the summer holidays.

You may inform the teacher that the bonus is being continued during the present fiscal year.

Secretary—
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find a bill for erecting a henhouse and driving-shed as explained in said bill. If this double building was erected now it would cost sixty or eighty dollars at the present rate of the material used.

I presented this bill to the Indian Council at their last sitting. The Council seemed to think that the Department had paid me this bill or pretended to think so. The Council decided to leave it to a Band meeting. Knowing well what a lot of irresponsible fellows at a Band meeting would do I withdrew the bill. The Agent advised me to sell the building. This I refuse to do. I prefer to leave it to the Indians rather than do a shabby trick of that kind.

I also, at my own expense, lined the two feed bins with tin sheeting to save the grain from rodents at an expense of $5.00.

Now I have a proposition to make to the Department viz:

When I came here over twenty-three years ago I brought with me a good store. I set
I own store and used it for years until it was burned out. The department then bought a store which I have been using since. Twice since the department purchased said store I have bought at my own expense new linings for the fire-box. All stone-pipes belong to me.

The building I erected has been utilized to store the school-garden tools, 5-shovels, 5-hoes, 2 garden-rakes and a watering can. Also to store the storm-windows & storm-door. Here is stored also the extension ladder.

If this building were not here the department would be under the necessity of providing a building for the safe storage of these things.

In lieu of this building and losing the feed bins and burning out my own store here will the Department allow me to take this store with me when I leave at the end of June?

If the department considers my proposition fair and reasonable I ask it to grant it. If not then we will let the matter drop but under no circumstances will I allow the bill to be brought before the Indian Council again as I consider they grossly insulted me by insinuating that the department paid this bill at the time viz October 1908.

Yours sincerely,

T.J. Wallace

Sir,

I have the honor to reply to your letter No. 31-1-5 of the 12th inst. re French Bay Indian school.

I might say that it would not be necessary to whitewash the walls of the school until next year as it would probably interfere with the classroom duties. The fallen whitewash in the closets can easily be swept out. The cement steps which have three sides to the entrance, two of which are chipped on the edges and the third is in as good repair as ever, and the pupils use this side. I took the matter of these steps up with the teacher the last time I visited the school and we both agreed that they could be held over until another year. My reason for doing this is that I am of the private opinion that this school will in a short time be closed as it is situated in the poorest part of the Reserve, and two families, Livingstone Ritchie and Alex Root are talking of buying property down near the Scotch Settlement portion. Mr. Parker on his last visit to the reserve was also of the same opinion.

Mr. McCool is apparently of the opinion that work done by the Government does not cost anything and as this Reserve has so many buildings to look after I don't care to spend any unnecessary money, and the schools in question are second to none in this vicinity.

I have the honor to remain,

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my visit of inspection to the Saugeen Agency.

FRENCH BAY SCHOOL: is no credit to us. If this school is to be maintained, a considerable expenditure will be necessary to put it in something like decent condition. The whole place looks like decay and neglect. The inside walls and woodwork need several coats of paint. All the outside woodwork around the windows, doors and belfry, needs painting. The chimney needs pointing and some bricks replaced. New wire and posts are needed for the fence enclosing the school grounds and residence. Some of the present posts might be used for the fence at the back end of the lot. The school grounds are very untidy and neglected looking.

The toilets at all the schools in your Agency should be thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good, sanitary condition during the summer holidays. You should arrange to have this work done, forwarding accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Hoey,

Segeen Agency,
French Bay Indian Day School.

The walls and ceiling of the classroom are in a disgraceful state. The paint on the woodwork has peeled off in streaks. The plaster has fallen down in some places. The metal ceiling is rusting into holes.

The outside woodwork is in a similar condition.

The two closets are beyond repair. They have probably done service for the life of the school and should be replaced.

A desk chair for the Teacher is needed, an old broken kitchen chair is in use at present.

The teacher asks to be supplied with a dozen desk ink wells. Small open bottles are being used and are constantly spilling. Similar wells to those supplied with new desks are what she wants.

A map of Bruce County for classroom work is needed. The School Inspector has criticised neglect in providing each of the three Day Schools in the Agency with this map.

TEACHER'S RESIDENCE.

The all metal siding is beginning to deteriorate, rust is causing damage and unless painted within a reasonable time the metal will decay beyond repair.

The inside plaster of the front porch is falling down, about half of it is already gone showing the bare laths.

The downstairs part - ceilings and walls - are giving way and need painting in the worst way.

The downstairs room used as a bedroom should have a congoelum rug on the floor. It is of soft boards, badly worn and splintered in places.

The teacher has to have a car but there is no accommodation for it at the school. The barn which is in fairly good repair could be used as a garage by building a plank entrance. The material is available at the Agency office and a handy Indian could do the job in a day or two at a total cost of $10.00 or less.

This whole school property in its present condition is not a good example to the Indians of how to take care of their own buildings.

RECOMMENDED:

1. A desk chair for classroom,
2. 1 Dozen ink wells
3. 1 map of Bruce County
4. 1 Congoelum rug for bedroom floor.
5. Alterations to barn to accommodate teacher's car.

Ottawa, January 30, 1937.

Dear Sir,

In reporting regarding his recent inspection of the French Bay Indian Day School, Inspector McCookin states that the walls, ceiling and woodwork of the classroom require painting, also that the plaster and the metal ceiling should be repaired. Please let me have an estimate of the cost of doing the necessary work in the above regard.

The Inspector also mentions that new closets are needed. An estimate of the cost of erecting new closets should also be given.

Please let me know the name of the manufacturer of the desks for which the twelve (12) ink wells are required.

The teacher asked Mr. McCookin for a map of Bruce County. Owing to their cost, we do not usually supply county maps. You might let me know what maps are at present in this school and their condition.

With regard to the teacher's residence, Mr. McCookin writes:

"The all metal siding is beginning to deteriorate, rust is causing damage and unless painted within a reasonable time the metal will decay beyond repair.

"The inside plaster of the front porch is falling down, about half of it is already gone showing the bare laths.

"The downstairs part - ceilings and walls - are giving way and need painting in the worst way."

Please submit an estimate of the cost of making the above improvements.

A request was also received from the teacher for repairs to the barn in order that he might use it as a garage. You should inform the teacher that the Department does not provide garages at Indian day schools.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

Schools.

Re: French Bay Indian Day School,
Saugeen Agency, Ontario.

On roll, 14; average attendance, 12.

The interior of the classroom is dingy and neglected looking. Plaster is broken in patches and the woodwork has become discoloured and dirty. If funds can be found, the classroom should be painted and cleaned up during the summer holidays.

There is an old dilapidated shed, 18'x12', on the school grounds, used as a chicken coop but useless now. I would suggest Agent Robertson be given permission to give it to an Indian to demolish and clean up the debris for the material. It is an eye-sore and useless for any purpose.

The double doors on the school shed are off. They should be patched and rehung. It looks careless to have them in the shape they are. An Indian could do this little job. The cost would not exceed $10.00. I would recommend Agent Robertson be instructed to have this done.

The teacher's residence needs redecorating inside and out. Nothing has been done to it for years and it is fast going to decay. It is a metal sheeted building and rust is beginning to show effects, several places the metal is eaten right through. The inside walls and ceilings are badly in need of redecorating.

The teacher complained that she had not got the school supplies requisitioned for in early September. I was there on the 25th October.

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my inspection of the Saugeen Agency on November 30th and December 2nd.

FRENCH BAY SCHOOL

The classroom has been much improved and brightened up since the walls and ceiling have been painted and the desks varnished last year. The outside woodwork, door and windows, should be painted as soon as possible to prevent further deterioration. The agent was instructed to get one of the Indians to make a small wood box for fuel and have it placed at the rear of the classroom, and also to have the stove pipes treated with stove enamel.
